opinion_summary: circuit courts do not have jurisdiction to review appeals pursuant to  usc (a)(), but district courts may hear habeas corpus petitions pursuant to  usc  in a challenge to the board of immigration appeals determination of ineligibility to apply for a discretionary waiver of deportation under  usc (c).
name: DEBORIS CALCANO-MARTINEZ, et al. v. IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE

opinion_summary: the illinois hmo act is a law which regulates insurance under erisa's saving clause, and because congressional intent did not override that clause, erisa does not preempt the illinois hmo act.
name: RUSH PRUDENTIAL HMO, INC. v. DEBRA C. MORAN et al.

opinion_summary: the statute of limitations under  usc p of the fair credit reporting act starts to run when the reporting agency made the erroneous report and not when the plaintiff discovered or should have discovered the misrepresentation.
name: TRW INC. v. ADELAIDE ANDREWS

opinion_summary: a violation of  u.s.c. section (c)()(a), for the use or carrying of a firearm during a drug trafficking crime, is a single offense in which brandishing and discharging are sentencing factors to be found by the judge, not offense elements to be found by the jury.
name: WILLIAM JOSEPH HARRIS v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: the eeoc's relation-back regulation is an unassailable interpretation of section  of title vii of the civil rights act of .
name: LEONARD EDELMAN v. LYNCHBURG COLLEGE

opinion_summary: peer grading, or allowing students to grade one another's tests, papers, and assignments while teachers explain the correct answers to the entire class does not violate the family educational rights and privacy act of  (ferpa), since student papers are not maintained under section g(a)()(a) of ferpa at the time students perform peer grading, nor do student graders constitute people who are acting for an educational institution under the statute.
name: OWASSO INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT NO. I-011, AKA OWASSO PUBLIC SCHOOLS, et al. v. KRISTJA J. FALVO, PARENT AND NEXT FRIEND OF HER MINOR CHILDREN, ELIZABETH PLETAN, PHILIP PLETAN, AND ERICA PLETAN

opinion_summary: to be substantially limited in a major life activity under the americans with disabilities act, an individual must have an impairment that prevents or severely restricts activities that are of central importance to most people's daily lives rather than just to a particular job.
name: TOYOTA MOTOR MANUFACTURING, KENTUCKY, INC. v. ELLA WILLIAMS

opinion_summary: moratoria on all development in lake tahoe basin area for a period totalling  months, imposed by a regional planning agency while formulating a land use plan for the area, were not per se takings of property requiring compensation under the takings clause.
name: TAHOE-SIERRA PRESERVATION COUNCIL, INC., et al. v. TAHOE REGIONAL PLANNING AGENCY et al.

opinion_summary: the sexual abuse treatment program serves the vital penological purpose of rehabilitation, and offering inmates minimal incentives to participate does not amount to compelled self-incrimination under the fifth amendment.
name: DAVID R. MCKUNE, WARDEN, et al. v. ROBERT G. LILE

opinion_summary: a federal habeas petition is not an application for state post-conviction or other collateral review within the meaning of  usc (d)(), and thus a first federal habeas petition does not toll the limitation period for subsequent petition.
name: GEORGE DUNCAN, SUPERINTENDENT, GREAT MEADOW CORRECTIONAL FACILITY v. SHERMAN WALKER

opinion_summary: a suspended sentence which may result in deprivation of liberty may not be imposed unless the defendant was accorded the assistance of counsel in the prosecution for the crime charged.
name: ALABAMA v. LEREED SHELTON

opinion_summary: a content-neutral permit scheme regulating uses of a public forum need not have procedural safeguards required for subject matter speech regulations.
name: CAREN CRONK THOMAS AND WINDY CITY HEMP DEVELOPMENT BOARD v. CHICAGO PARK DISTRICT

opinion_summary: in an action brought under the americans with disabilities act of , an employer's showing that an employee's requested accommodation conflicts with its seniority rules is ordinarily sufficient to show, as a matter of law, that the accommodation is not reasonable, however, the employee remains free to present evidence of special circumstances that makes a seniority rule exception reasonable in the particular case; here, because the district court took a different view, and neither party has had opportunity to seek summary judgment in accordance with principles announced in opinion, court of appeals' judgment vacated and case remanded for further proceedings.
name: US AIRWAYS, INC. v. ROBERT BARNETT

opinion_summary: probation condition that defendant submit himself to warrantless searches is not limited only to searches with a probationary purpose.
name: UNITED STATES v. MARK JAMES KNIGHTS

opinion_summary: the child online protection act's (copa) use of community standards to identify what material is harmful to minors does not by itself render the copa statute substantially overbroad under the first amendment.
name: JOHN ASHCROFT, ATTORNEY GENERAL v. AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION, et al.

opinion_summary: the plain language of the coal industry retiree health benefit act of  does not permit the commissioner to assign health care benefit premiums of retired miners to the successors in interest of out-of-business signatory operators.
name: JO ANNE B. BARNHART, COMMISSIONER OF SOCIAL SECURITY v. SIGMON COAL COMPANY, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: the americans with disabilities act does not preclude an eeoc regulation which allows an employer's defense that a worker's disability on the job would present a direct threat to his or her health.
name: CHEVRON U.S.A. INC. v. MARIO ECHAZABAL

opinion_summary: the controlled substances act,  usc  et seq., does not permit distribution of marijuana except for research purposes, and medical necessity is not a legally cognizable defense to violations of the act.
name: UNITED STATES v. OAKLAND CANNABIS BUYERS' COOPERATIVE AND JEFFREY JONES

opinion_summary: the federal supplemental jurisdiction statute,  u.s.c. section , will not toll the statute of limitations for state law claims made against nonconsenting state defendants that are dismissed on eleventh amendment grounds.
name: LANCE RAYGOR AND JAMES GOODCHILD v. REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA, et al.

opinion_summary: under the totality of the circumstances test for investigatory stops, an officer may rely on combination of otherwise innocent observations to briefly pull over a suspect vehicle.
name: UNITED STATES v. RALPH ARVIZU

opinion_summary: california labor code provisions allowing state to require contractors to withhold payment to subcontractors who fail to comply with labor code do not violate due process because subcontractor may recover fees by filing a breach of contract suit against the state.
name: ARTHUR S. LUJAN, LABOR COMMISSIONER OF CALIFORNIA, et al. v. G & G FIRE SPRINKLERS, INC.

opinion_summary: jurisdiction is found under  u.s.c. section , for a local-exchange carrier's claim that a state public utility commission's order, requiring reciprocal compensation for isp-bound calls, is pre-empted by federal law; suit against commissioners in their individual capacities is not barred by ex parte young,  u.s. , where no past liability of the state or its commissioners is at issue.
name: VERIZON MD. INC. v. PUBLIC SERVICE COMM'N OF MD.

opinion_summary: prosecution history estoppel may apply to any claim amendment made to satisfy the patent act's requirements, not just to amendments made to avoid the prior art, but estoppel need not bar suit against every equivalent to the amended claim element.
name: FESTO CORPORATION v. SHOKETSU KINZOKU KOGYO KABUSHIKI CO., LTD., et al.

opinion_summary: the lookback period under section (a)()(a)(i) of the bankruptcy code is tolled during the pendency of a prior bankruptcy petition, making an irs claim for debtor's taxes non-dischargeable due to the automatic stay imposed under  u.s.c. section  during a prior chapter  bankruptcy proceeding, even if debtors obtained a discharge under their newer chapter  petition.
name: CORNELIUS P. YOUNG, ET UX. v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: where groups of affiliated corporations elect to file a consolidated federal income tax return, the group must take deductions as a single-entity and not by aggregating product liability losses separately determined company by company.
name: UNITED DOMINION INDUSTRIES, INC. v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: federal immigration policy, as expressed by congress in the immigration reform and control act of , foreclosed the nlrb from awarding backpay to an undocumented alien who has never been legally authorized to work in the united states but has been terminated from his us job in violation of the national labor relations act.
name: HOFFMAN PLASTIC COMPOUNDS, INC. v. NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD

opinion_summary: a title vii plaintiff must file his discriminatory or retaliatory employment claims within the appropriate - or - day period, but a hostile work environment charge is not time barred if all acts underlying the claim are part of the same unlawful practice, and at least one act falls within the filing period; equitable doctrines may toll or limit either period.
name: NATIONAL RAILROAD PASSENGER CORPORATION v. ABNER MORGAN, JR.

opinion_summary: provisions of a village ordinance, making it a misdemeanor to engage in door-to-door neighborhood canvassing without first registering with the mayor's office and receiving a permit, violate the first amendment as it applies to religious proselytizing, anonymous political speech, and the distribution of hand bills.
name: WATCHTOWER BIBLE AND TRACT SOCIETY OF NEW YORK, INC., et al. v. VILLAGE OF STRATTON et al.

opinion_summary: a program giving educational choices and aid to certain students attending both religious and non-religious public and private schools, enacted for the valid secular purpose of providing educational assistance to poor children, is one of true private choice and does not offend the first amendment's establishment clause.
name: SUSAN TAVE ZELMAN, SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION OF OHIO, et al. v. DORIS SIMMONS-HARRIS et al.

opinion_summary: section d(l)() of the anti-drug abuse act of ,  u.s.c. (), gives local public housing authorities discretion to evict public housing tenants when either a member of the tenant's household or a guest engages in drug-related criminal activity, regardless of whether the tenant knew, or had reason to know, about such activity.
name: DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT v. PEARLIE RUCKER et al.

opinion_summary: a husband's interests in a piece of property, owned with his wife as tenants by the entirety under michigan law, constitute property or rights to property to which a federal tax lien may attach pursuant to  u.s.c. section .
name: UNITED STATES v. SANDRA L. CRAFT

opinion_summary: an employment discrimination complaint need not contain specific facts establishing a prima facie case under the framework set forth in mcdonnell douglas corp. v. green,  u.s. , , but instead must contain only a short and plain statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief per fed. r. civ. proc. (a)().
name: AKOS SWIERKIEWICZ v. SOREMA N. A.

opinion_summary: federal government holds title, in trust for the coeur dalene tribe, to lands underlying portions of lake coeur dalene and the st. joe river.
name: IDAHO v. UNITED STATES et al.

opinion_summary: states may restrict a party's coordinated expenditures to minimize circumvention of the federal election campaign act's contribution limits because coordinated expenditures are not like independent expenditures.
name: FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION v. COLORADO REPUBLICAN FEDERAL CAMPAIGN COMMITTEE

opinion_summary: the social security admin.'s interpretation that the -month duration requirement in a statute that authorizes disability and ssi payments to individuals applies to both the inability to engage in work as well as the impairment, was within its lawful interpretative authority; thus, benefits to worker denied because his inability to engage in substantial gainful activity lasted only  months.
name: JO ANNE B. BARNHART, COMMISSIONER OF SOCIAL SECURITY v. CLEVELAND B. WALTON

opinion_summary: databases that reproduce and distribute articles standing alone and not in context, and not as part of that particular collective work to which the author contributed, are not revisions for purposes of the  usc (c) safe harbor from copyright infringement.
name: NEW YORK TIMES COMPANY, INC., et al. v. JONATHAN TASINI, et al.

opinion_summary: back wages are subject to fica and futa taxes in the year the wages were actually paid, and not the year that they should have been paid.
name: UNITED STATES v. CLEVELAND INDIANS BASEBALL COMPANY

opinion_summary: usc (a) forbids a public accommodation from discriminating against either spectators or competitors on the basis of disability, and use of a golf cart during golf match does not fundamentally alter the game.
name: PGA TOUR, INC. v. CASEY MARTIN

opinion_summary: forced subsidy for generic advertising is a violation of the first amendment where the advertising is not merely ancillary to a more comprehensive program restricting marketing autonomy, but instead is the principal object of the regulatory scheme.
name: UNITED STATES AND DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE v. UNITED FOODS, INC.

opinion_summary: where an arbitration clause in the contract proposed by the indian tribe specifies the enforcement of arbitral awards in any court having jurisdiction thereof, the indian tribe has waived its immunity to suit in state court.
name: C & L ENTERPRISES, INC. v. CITIZEN BAND POTAWATOMI INDIAN TRIBE OF OKLAHOMA

opinion_summary: even though not specifically recognized by any admiralty statute, the negligent breach of a general maritime duty of care is actionable under maritime common law when it causes death, as it is when it causes injury.
name: NORFOLK SHIPBUILDING & DRYDOCK CORPORATION v. CELESTINE GARRIS, ADMINISTRATRIX OF THE ESTATE OF CHRISTOPHER GARRIS, DECEASED

opinion_summary: secretly intending never to honor an oral grant of an option to buy stock violates section (b) of the securities exchange act of , which prohibits using a manipulative or deceptive device or contrivance in connection with the purchase or sale of any security.
name: THE WHARF (HOLDINGS) LIMITED, et al. v. UNITED INTERNATIONAL HOLDINGS, INC. et al.

opinion_summary: the navajo nation's imposition of a hotel occupancy tax upon nonmembers on non-indian fee land within its reservation is invalid.
name: ATKINSON TRADING COMPANY, INC. v. JOE SHIRLEY, JR., et al.

opinion_summary: under the interstate agreement on detainers, states receiving criminal defendants prior to the termination of a sentence in another state may not arraign the defendant and then return the prisoner before trial.
name: ALABAMA v. MICHAEL HERMAN BOZEMAN

opinion_summary: usc (d)() of the indian regulatory gaming act does not exempt tribes from paying gambling-related taxes imposed by chapter  of the internal revenue code even if chapter  exempts some state-controlled gambling activities.
name: CHICKASAW NATION v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: the fcc can require state utility commissions to set rates charged by incumbent telephone service carriers for leased elements on a forward-looking basis, untied to the incumbents' actual investment.
name: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS INC., et al. v. FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION, et al.

opinion_summary: where a the does not instruct the jury that a life sentence would be without parole, simmons v. south carolina,  us  (), applies and due process entitles the defendant to inform the jury of his ineligibility for parole.
name: WESLEY AARON SHAFER, JR. v. SOUTH CAROLINA

opinion_summary: a person who is the president and sole shareholder of a closely held corporation, acting within the scope of his authority as corporate employee, may be distinct from the enterprise for purposes of  usc (c), the rico statute.
name: CEDRIC KUSHNER PROMOTIONS, LTD. v. DON KING, et al.

opinion_summary: while section  of the federal power act (fpa) gives the federal government control over management of the country's power grids, f.e.r.c. is not required under section  of the fpa to regulate bundled retail power transmissions or to order universal unbundling where it determines that a remedy it orders sufficiently responds to regulating the wholesale energy market.
name: NEW YORK et al. v. FEDERAL ENERGY REGULATORY COMMISSION et al.

opinion_summary: the federal cigarette labeling and advertising act,  usc , preempts state regulation of advertising or promotion of cigarettes, including regulations governing outdoor and point-of-sale advertising of cigarettes, but not regulation of actual sales or use of cigarettes.
name: LORILLARD TOBACCO COMPANY, et al. v. THOMAS F. REILLY, ATTORNEY GENERAL OF MASSACHUSETTS, et al.

opinion_summary: the cage rule, that a jury instruction is unconstitutional if there is a reasonable likelihood that the jury understood the instruction to allow conviction without proof beyond a reasonable doubt, is not retroactive to cases on collateral review by the supreme court.
name: MELVIN TYLER v. BURL CAIN, WARDEN

opinion_summary: cfr .(a), a labor department regulation, is contrary to the family and medical leave act of  and beyond the secretary of labor's authority.
name: TRACY RAGSDALE, et al. v. WOLVERINE WORLD WIDE, INC.

opinion_summary: the failure to sign an otherwise timely and complete notice of appeal does not require the court of appeals to dismiss the appeal.
name: DALE G. BECKER v. BETTY MONTGOMERY, ATTORNEY GENERAL OF OHIO, et al.

opinion_summary: in an asset forfeiture proceeding, where the government sends notice of forfeiture proceeding by certified mail to prisoner in prison that has a system for delivering mail to inmates, due process is satisfied.
name: LARRY DEAN DUSENBERY v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: where defendant has offered extensive evidence that he was mentally retarded and had been severely abused as a child, the jury may consider and give mitigating effect to that evidence in imposing sentence.
name: JOHN PAUL PENRY v. GARY L. JOHNSON, DIRECTOR, TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE, INSTITUTIONAL DIVISION

opinion_summary: failure of a criminal defendant to make a written motion for continuance under missouri court rule . does not constitute adequate state grounds to deny federal habeas review, where original denial was not based on this ground and was not strictly observed.
name: REMON LEE v. MIKE KEMNA, SUPERINTENDENT, CROSSROADS CORRECTIONAL CENTER

opinion_summary: the merit systems protection board may independently review prior disciplinary actions against a government employee even if those prior actions are pending in a negotiated grievance procedure.
name: UNITED STATES POSTAL SERVICE v. MARIA A. GREGORY

opinion_summary: front pay awards are not an element of compensatory damages under the civil rights act of  so they are not subject to the statutory damages cap.
name: SHARON B. POLLARD v. E. I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & COMPANY

opinion_summary: where lawful permament resident would have been eligible for a waiver of deportation under the immigration law in effect when he was convicted, but commenced removal proceedings after aedpas and iiriras effective dates, the discretionary relief is still available.
name: IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE v. ENRICO ST. CYR

opinion_summary: section ()(b) of the child pornography prevention act of , which bans virtual child pornography, and section ()(d), which prohibits the production of pornographic material pandered as child pornography, abridge the freedom to engage in a substantial amount of protected, lawful speech, and are therefore unconstitutional and overbroad.
name: JOHN D. ASHCROFT, ATTORNEY GENERAL, et al. v. THE FREE SPEECH COALITION et al.

opinion_summary: city may reasonably rely on a  study, showing increased crime rates in an area with the largest concentration of adult establishments, to demonstrate that a present ban on multiple-use adult establishments serves its interest in reducing crime.
name: CITY OF LOS ANGELES v. ALAMEDA BOOKS, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: usc (b) of the pole attachments act, which requires the federal communications commission to set reasonable rates for attachments to telephone and electric poles, also applies to attachments that provide high-speed internet access at the same time as cable television.
name: NATIONAL CABLE & TELECOMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION, INC. v. GULF POWER COMPANY et al.

opinion_summary: florida supreme court decision mandating hand recount in  presidential election has considerable uncertainty as to the precise grounds for the decision, warranting vacateur and remand to that court.
name: GEORGE W. BUSH v. PALM BEACH COUNTY CANVASSING BOARD, et al.

opinion_summary: executions of mentally retarded criminals are cruel and unusual punishments prohibited by the eighth amendment.
name: DARYL RENARD ATKINS v. VIRGINIA

opinion_summary: the prison litigation reform act and its exhaustion requirement are applicable to all inmate lawsuits regarding prison life, regardless of whether the suit involves general circumstances or particular episodes, and whether the pleadings allege excessive force or another wrong.
name: CORRECTION OFFICER PORTER, et al. v. RONALD NUSSLE

opinion_summary: prisoners may not bring bivens actions against a private corporation operating a prison under contract with the bureau of prisons.
name: CORRECTIONAL SERVICES CORPORATION v. JOHN E. MALESKO

opinion_summary: coast guard's refusal to regulate working conditions on uninspected vessels does not preclude osha regulations on those vessels.
name: ELAINE L. CHAO, SECRETARY OF LABOR v. MALLARD BAY DRILLING, INC.

opinion_summary: evidence of defendant's violent conduct in prison is relevant to issue of defendant's future danger to society in death penalty cases, such that defendant is entitled to a jury instruction of life in prison without parole as an alternative.
name: WILLIAM ARTHUR KELLY v. SOUTH CAROLINA

opinion_summary: in order to demonstrate a sixth amendment violation where the trial court fails to inquire into a potential conflict of interest about which it knew or reasonably should have known, a defendant must establish that the conflict adversely affected his counsel's performance; here, even though defendant's counsel represented the victim in a previous case and did not notify the defendant, court or co-counsel of the potential conflict, no violation found.
name: WALTER MICKENS, JR. v. JOHN TAYLOR, WARDEN

opinion_summary: the absence of specific uniform standards for manual vote recounts, especially where the evidence shows that vote counting standards varied or changed within counties, violates the equal protection clause.
name: GEORGE W. BUSH AND RICHARD CHENEY v. ALBERT GORE, JR., et al.

opinion_summary: the income-first method used by most states to calculate medicaid eligibility for nursing home residents, which requires that potential income transfers from the institutionalized spouse be deemed community spouse's income for purposes of determining such eligibility, does not conflict with the medicare catastrophic coverage act of , enacted to protect the financial well-being of spouses of institutionalized nursing home residents.
name: WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND FAMILY SERVICES v. IRENE BLUMER

opinion_summary: a state must show that a sexual offender lacks some ability to control his violent behavior to justify confining him under its sexually violent predator laws.
name: KANSAS v. MICHAEL T. CRANE

opinion_summary: a criminal defendant who knowingly and voluntarily enters a guilty plea under fed. r. crim. p. (h), without objection, carries the burden of showing plain-error under fed. r. crim. p. , and a reviewing court may consult the entire record when considering the effect of any error on defendant's substantial rights.
name: UNITED STATES v. ALPHONSO VONN

opinion_summary: a panel of the ninth circuit court of appeals consisting of two article iii judges and one article iv territorial-court judge did not have authority to decide petitioners' appeals, as a judge of the district court for the northern mariana islands was not a district judge under  u.s.c. section (a).
name: KHANH PHUONG NGUYEN v. UNITED STATES et al.

opinion_summary: u.s.c. section (b)()(a), authorizing that an attorney representing a social security claimant receive  percent of past-due benefits awarded, does not displace contingent-fee agreements within the statutory ceiling, but instead instructs courts to review fees under those agreements for reasonableness.
name: GARY E. GISBRECHT, BARBARA A. MILLER, AND NANCY SANDINE v. JO ANNE B. BARNHART, COMMISSIONER OF SOCIAL SECURITY

opinion_summary: employees of the state of nevada may recover money damages in the event of the state's failure to comply with the family-care provision of the family and medical leave act of , and such a claim is not barred by the eleventh amendment.
name: NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES, et al. v. WILLIAM HIBBS et al.

opinion_summary: in determining whether shareholder-directors of a corporation should be counted as employees under the ada, courts should assess whether the shareholder-directors operate independently and manage the business, or instead are subject to the firm's control.
name: CLACKAMAS GASTROENTEROLOGY ASSOCIATES, P. C. v. DEBORAH WELLS

opinion_summary: a  u.s.c. section  plaintiff's fifth amendment rights were not violated through questioning by police, where he was never charged and no statements were used against him. questioning of plaintiff while he was being treated for gunshot wounds after an altercation with police did not violate his fourteenth amendment rights.
name: BEN CHAVEZ v. OLIVERIO MARTINEZ

opinion_summary: a complaint for fraud and misappropriation of proceeds from securities transactions, against a broker in connection with management of an investment account, sufficiently alleged conduct in connection with the purchase or sale of any security under the securities exchange act of  and sec rule (b)().
name: SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. CHARLES ZANDFORD

opinion_summary: congress may require that deportable criminal aliens be detained for the brief period necessary for removal proceedings. federal courts have jurisdiction to review a constitutional challenge to a detention under the immigration and nationality act,  u.s.c. section (c).
name: CHARLES DEMORE, DISTRICT DIRECTOR, SAN FRANCISCO DISTRICT OF IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE, et al. v. HYUNG JOON KIM

opinion_summary: an ineffective assistance of counsel claim may be brought in a collateral proceeding under  u.s.c. section , whether or not the petitioner could have raised the claim on direct appeal.
name: JOSEPH MASSARO v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: california's law extending the statute of limitations for prosecuting sex-related child abuse, which had the effect of revising previously time-barred prosecutions under earlier statutes of limitations, violates the constitution's ex-post facto clause, art. i, section , cl. .
name: MARION REYNOLDS STOGNER v. CALIFORNIA

opinion_summary: states may maintain fraud actions when fundraisers make false or misleading representations designed to deceive donors about how their donations will be used, consistent with supreme court precedent and the first amendment.
name: ILLINOIS ex rel. LISA MADIGAN, ATTORNEY GENERAL OF ILLINOIS v. TELEMARKETING ASSOCIATES, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: a preliminary injunction preventing implementation of a state program reducing prescription drug prices for state residents was improper, where an association of non-resident drug manufacturers could not show probability of success on commerce clause claims.
name: PHARMACEUTICAL RESEARCH AND MANUFACTURERS OF AMERICA v. PETER E. WALSH, ACTING COMMISSIONER, MAINE DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES, et al.

opinion_summary: the interstate commerce commission's interpretation of the intermodal surface transportation efficiency act's fee-cap provision is consistent with the language of that statute and reasonably resolves ambiguity therein, thus that interpretation must receive deference under chevron u.s.a., inc. v. natural resources defense council, inc.,  u.s. .
name: YELLOW TRANSPORTATION, INC. v. MICHIGAN, et al.

opinion_summary: a state waives its eleventh amendment immunity when it voluntarily invokes federal court jurisdiction by removing a case from state court to federal court.
name: PAUL D. LAPIDES v. BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY SYSTEM OF GEORGIA, et al.

opinion_summary: a state prisoner's application for state collateral review is pending, for purposes of tolling the one-year time period to seek federal habeas relief, during the time between a lower state court's decision and the filing of a notice of appeal to a higher state court.
name: TOM L. CAREY, WARDEN v. TONY EUGENE SAFFOLD

opinion_summary: corrections officers were not entitled to qualified immunity for acts of handcuffing an inmate to a hitching post, because a reasonable corrections officer would have known that such punishment was unlawful under the eighth amendment, based on the lack of any safety concern or emergency, and obvious cruelty inherent in such a practice.
name: LARRY HOPE v. MARK PELZER et al.

opinion_summary: a school district policy, requiring students participating in extracurricular activities to consent to drug testing, reasonably furthers the district's important interest in preventing and deterring drug use by students, and does not violate the fourth amendment.
name: BOARD OF EDUCATION OF INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT NO. 92 OF POTTAWATOMIE COUNTY, et al. v. LINDSAY EARLS et al.

opinion_summary: the food and drug modernization act of 's prohibitions on soliciting prescriptions for, and advertising, compounded drugs, which are exempt from the fda's standard drug approval requirements, amount to an unconstitutional restriction on commercial speech.
name: TOMMY G. THOMPSON, SECRETARY OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, et al. v. WESTERN STATES MEDICAL CENTER et al.

opinion_summary: a claim by a woman, whose husband was allegedly killed by guatemalan officers paid by the cia, did not state a cause of action for constitutional denial of judicial access based on the government's alleged concealment of information regarding the incident, where the underlying cause of action and remedy compromised were not identified.
name: WARREN CHRISTOPHER, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE, et al. v. JENNIFER K. HARBURY

opinion_summary: state court's finding, that defense counsel's failure to present mitigating evidence against imposition of the death penalty, and waiver of final argument did not amount to ineffective assistance, was neither contrary to nor an unreasonable application of federal law under the strickland standard.
name: RICKY BELL, WARDEN v. GARY BRADFORD CONE

opinion_summary: where a complaint seeks declaratory judgment of non-infringement of trade dress and an injunction against such accusations, but does not assert a patent law claim, the federal circuit court of appeals cannot assert jurisdiction over the case, although the answer contains a patent law counterclaim.
name: THE HOLMES GROUP, INC. v. VORNADO AIR CIRCULATION SYSTEMS, INC.

opinion_summary: an unnamed class member, who objects in a timely manner to the approval of a settlement at a fairness hearing, may bring an appeal without first intervening.
name: ROBERT J. DEVLIN v. ROBERT A. SCARDELLETTI et al.

opinion_summary: u.s.c. section (c), which preempts prescriptions by a state related to a price, route, or service of any motor carrier with respect to the transportation of property, does not bar a state from delegating to municipalities and other local units the state's authority to establish safety regulations governing motor carriers of property, including tow trucks.
name: CITY OF COLUMBUS, et al. v. OURS GARAGE AND WRECKER SERVICE, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: because enactment of the emergency low income housing preservation act qualified as a repudiation of a housing loan, not a present breach of the loan agreements, the six-year statute of limitations began to run when mortgagees tendered prepayment, and the government dishonored its obligation to accept the tender and release control over use of property securing the loan.
name: FRANCONIA ASSOCIATES, et al. v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: state sovereign immunity bars the federal maritime commission from adjudicating a private party's complaint against the south carolina state ports authority, an arm of the state of south carolina.
name: FEDERAL MARITIME COMMISSION v. SOUTH CAROLINA STATE PORTS AUTHORITY et al.

opinion_summary: tax law authorizes the irs to use the aggregate estimation method in examining a restaurant's credit card slips and assessing an employer's federal insurance contribution act liability, rather than determining the amount of tips actually received by each employee.
name: UNITED STATES v. FIOR D'ITALIA, INC.

opinion_summary: the state of arizona's enumerated aggravating factors which allow for imposition of the death penalty, amount to the functional equivalent of an element of a greater offense, which must be found by a jury under apprendi, and may not be determined by a sentencing judge.
name: TIMOTHY STUART RING v. ARIZONA

opinion_summary: the nlrb's definition of a retaliatory suit (by an employer against a union) as one brought with a motive to interfere with the exercise of protected rights under the national labor relations act, is invalid because it covers a substantial amount of genuine petitioning.
name: BE & K CONSTRUCTION COMPANY v. NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD et al.

opinion_summary: a canon of judicial conduct, prohibiting a candidate for judicial office from announcing his or her views on disputed legal or political issues, violates the first amendment; the canon is not narrowly tailored to serve impartiality, the pursuit of which is not a compelling state interest.
name: REPUBLICAN PARTY OF MINNESOTA, et al. v. SUZANNE WHITE, CHAIRPERSON, MINNESOTA BOARD OF JUDICIAL STANDARDS, et al.

opinion_summary: a corporation is an instrumentality of a foreign state under the foreign sovereign immunities act of  only if the foreign state itself owns a majority of the corporation's shares. instrumentality status is determined at the time of the filing of a complaint.
name: DOLE FOOD COMPANY, et al. v. GERARDO DENNIS PATRICKSON et al.

opinion_summary: the constitution does not require that the government disclose material impeachment evidence, or affirmative defense information, prior to entering a plea agreement with a defendant.
name: UNITED STATES v. ANGELA RUIZ

opinion_summary: the fourth amendment does not require police officers to advise bus passengers of their right not to cooperate and to refuse consent to searches.
name: UNITED STATES v. CHRISTOPHER DRAYTON AND CLIFTON BROWN, JR.

opinion_summary: a corporation organized under the laws of the british virgin islands is a citizen or subject of a foreign state for the purposes of alienage diversity jurisdiction under  u.s.c. section (a)().
name: JPMORGAN CHASE BANK v. TRAFFIC STREAM (BVI) INFRASTRUCTURE LIMITED

opinion_summary: the family educational rights and privacy act's non-disclosure of information provisions create no personal right to enforce under  u.s.c. section , enforcement of individual rights.
name: GONZAGA UNIVERSITY AND ROBERTA S. LEAGUE v. JOHN DOE

opinion_summary: punitive damages are not available in private suits brought under section  of the americans with disabilities act, which prohibits discrimination against the disabled by public entities, and section  of the rehabilitation act, which prohibits discrimination against the disabled by recipients of federal funding, including private organizations.
name: KAY BARNES, ETC., et al. v. JEFFREY GORMAN

opinion_summary: omission from a federal indictment of a fact enhancing the statutory maximum sentence (here quantity of drugs) does not justify a court of appeals to vacate the enhanced sentence, even where defendant did not object in trial court; indictment defects do not deprive a court of its power to adjudicate a case.
name: UNITED STATES v. LEONARD COTTON, MARQUETTE HALL, LAMONT THOMAS, MATILDA HALL, JOVAN POWELL, JESUS HALL, AND STANLEY HALL, JR.

opinion_summary: the absence of an actual denial by the bureau of alcohol, tobacco, and firearms (atf) of a felon's petition for relief from a firearms disability precludes judicial review available under  u.s.c. section (c).
name: UNITED STATES, et al. v. THOMAS LAMAR BEAN

opinion_summary: a state common law tort action seeking damages from the manufacturer of an outboard motor, after a boating accident, is not pre-empted by either ) the federal boat safety act of , or ) a coast guard decision as to regulation of propeller guards.
name: REX R. SPRIETSMA, ADMINISTRATOR OF THE ESTATE OF JEANNE SPRIETSMA, DECEASED v. MERCURY MARINE, A DIVISION OF BRUNSWICK CORPORATION

opinion_summary: the census bureau's use of hot-deck imputation in a population count, giving the state of utah one less congressional representative than if the bureau had filled information gaps with zero counts, does not constitute impermissible sampling under  u.s.c. section , which requires a decennial census, and does not violate the constitution's census clause.
name: UTAH, et al. v. DONALD L. EVANS, SECRETARY OF COMMERCE, et al.

opinion_summary: the all writs act, alone or in combination with the existence of ancillary jurisdiction in a federal court, is not a substitute for  u.s.c. section 's requirement that a federal court have original jurisdiction over an action in order for it to be removed from state court.
name: SYNGENTA CROP PROTECTION, INC., ROBERT BABB, EDEE TEMPLET, AND KENNETH A. DEVUN v. HURLEY HENSON

opinion_summary: a national association of securities dealers (nasd) arbitrator, rather than a district court, should apply a nasd time limit rule to an underlying dispute between an investment company and its client.
name: KAREN HOWSAM, ETC. v. DEAN WITTER REYNOLDS, INC.

opinion_summary: california's milk pricing and pooling regulations are not exempted from commerce clause scrutiny by the federal agriculture and reform act of . absence of an express statement identifying out-of-state residency or citizenship as a basis for disparate treatment is not a sufficient basis for rejecting privileges and immunities clause claims.
name: HILLSIDE DAIRY INC., A&A DAIRY, L&S DAIRY, AND MILKY WAY FARMS v. WILLIAM J. LYONS, JR., SECRETARY, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE, et al.

opinion_summary: in a capital murder case involving a defendant with an iq of , a coa should have issued, because a reasonable jurist could have found the district court's assessment of constitutional claims, relating to defendant's low iq, debatable or wrong.
name: ROBERT JAMES TENNARD v. DOUG DRETKE, DIRECTOR, TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE, CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTIONS DIVISION

opinion_summary: four justices conclude that the prime-plus or formula rate best meets the purposes of the bankruptcy code's cram down provision; because the proposed .% interest rate is higher than the risk-free rate, it is sufficient to account for the time value of money, which is all  u.s.c. section (a)()(b)(ii) requires.
name: LEE M. TILL, ET UX. v. SCS CREDIT CORPORATION

opinion_summary: texas law criminalizing two people of the same sex from engaging in private, consensual sex is unconstitutional, and the supreme court's decision in bowers v. hardwick is overturned. individual decisions regarding private, consensual intimate physical relationships are a form of liberty protected by the due process clause of the fourteenth amendment.
name: JOHN GEDDES LAWRENCE AND TYRON GARNER v. TEXAS

opinion_summary: in a maritime case involving a train wreck, plaintiff-railroad company is protected by the himalaya clause in the bill of lading, which extends the liability limitation broadly and corresponds to the fact that various modes of transportation would be involved in performing the contract.
name: NORFOLK SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY v. JAMES N. KIRBY, PTY LTD., DBA KIRBY ENGINEERING, AND ALLIANZ AUSTRALIA INSURANCE LIMITED

opinion_summary: brief highway checkpoint stops, when appropriately tailored by police seeking information about a crime of considerable public concern that was in all likelihood committed by others, do not violate the fourth amendment rights of motorists.
name: ILLINOIS v. ROBERT S. LIDSTER

opinion_summary: the adea's text, structure, purpose, history, and relationship to other federal statutes show that the statute does not mean to stop an employer from favoring an older employee over a younger one. thus, it does not protect plaintiffs-employees, all between  and  years old, who were denied health benefits under the terms of a collective bargaining agreement.
name: GENERAL DYNAMICS LAND SYSTEMS, INC. v. DENNIS CLINE et al.

opinion_summary: failure to give as suspect full miranda warnings does not require the suppression of the physical fruits of the suspect's unwarned, voluntary statements.
name: UNITED STATES v. SAMUEL FRANCIS PATANE

opinion_summary: an investment scheme promising a fixed rate of return can be an investment contract and thus a security subject to the federal securities laws. there is no reason to distinguish between promises of fixed returns and promises of variable returns when determining whether a particular scheme is an investment contract.
name: SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION v. CHARLES E. EDWARDS

opinion_summary: a cause of action arises under an act of congress enacted after december ,  - and therefore is governed by  u.s.c. section 's four-year statute of limitations - if the claim was made possible by a post- enactment. because petitioners' causes of action arose under the civil rights act of , they are not time-barred.
name: EDITH JONES et al., ON BEHALF OF HERSELF AND A CLASS OF OTHERS SIMILARLY SITUATED v. R. R. DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY

opinion_summary: the class of entities contemplated by  u.s.c. section  does not include a state's own subdivisions; that preemption provision does not affect the power of states and localities to restrict their own (or their political inferiors') delivery of telecommunications services.
name: JEREMIAH W. (JAY) NIXON, ATTORNEY GENERAL OF MISSOURI v. MISSOURI MUNICIPAL LEAGUE et al.

opinion_summary: plaintiff is not subject to antitrust liability. in both form and function, it is not a separate antitrust person from the us but is part of the government, and so is not controlled by the antitrust laws.
name: UNITED STATES POSTAL SERVICE v. FLAMINGO INDUSTRIES (USA) LTD. et al.

opinion_summary: washington state's exclusion of the pursuit of a devotional theology degree from its otherwise-inclusive scholarship aid program does not violate the free exercise clause. the state's interest in not funding the pursuit of devotional degrees is substantial, and the exclusion of such funding places a relatively minor burden on program scholars.
name: GARY LOCKE, GOVERNOR OF WASHINGTON, et al. v. JOSHUA DAVEY

opinion_summary: local fleet rules generally prohibiting the purchase or lease by various public and private fleet operators of vehicles that do not comply with stringent emission requirements appear to be preempted, in whole or in part, by section (a) of the clean air act. the rules do not escape preemption just because they address the purchase of vehicles, rather than their manufacture or sale.
name: ENGINE MANUFACTURERS ASSOCIATION AND WESTERN STATES PETROLEUM ASSOCIATION v. SOUTH COAST AIR QUALITY MANAGEMENT DISTRICT et al.

opinion_summary: defendant is liable for the death of an international passenger because its conduct here constitutes an accident under article  of the warsaw convention. flight attendant's refusal to reseat the asthmatic passenger away from the smoking section was clearly external to him, and unexpected and unusual in light of industry standards, defendant's policy, and the simple nature of the requested accommodation.
name: OLYMPIC AIRWAYS v. RUBINA HUSAIN, INDIVIDUALLY AND AS PERSONAL REPRESENTATIVE OF THE ESTATE OF ABID M. HANSON, DECEASED, et al.

opinion_summary: where an officer intentionally withheld miranda warnings, obtained a confession, then issued miranda warnings and elicited a second confession, the court found that both confessions were inadmissible as violating the defendant-s fifth amendment rights.
name: MISSOURI v. PATRICE SEIBERT.

opinion_summary: plaintiff must prove some actual damages to qualify for the minimum statutory award under the privacy act of . his uncorroborated claim of emotional distress, on learning of defendant's improper disclosure of his social security number in connection with his black lung benefits claim, is not compensable.
name: BUCK DOE v. ELAINE L. CHAO, SECRETARY OF LABOR

opinion_summary: the proper tax assessment against a partnership suffices to extend the statute of limitations to collect the tax in a judicial proceeding from the general partners who are liable for the payment of the partnership's debts. once a tax has been properly assessed, nothing in the internal revenue code requires the irs to separately assess the same tax against individuals who are not the actual taxpayers but are, by reason of state law, liable for the taxpayer's debt.
name: UNITED STATES v. ABEL COSMO GALLETTI et al.

opinion_summary: the government's promise to pay contract support costs that two indian tribes incurred for health services that a government agency, the indian health service, would otherwise have provided, is legally binding.
name: CHEROKEE NATION OF OKLAHOMA AND SHOSHONE-PAIUTE TRIBES OF THE DUCK VALLEY RESERVATION v. MICHAEL O. LEAVITT, SECRETARY OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, et al.

opinion_summary: for a right-to-counsel waiver at the plea stage to be knowing and intelligent, it is sufficient that the trial court inform the accused of the nature of the charges against him, of his right to be counseled regarding his plea, and of the range of allowable punishments attendant upon the entry of a guilty plea. he need not be warned of the risk that a viable defense will be overlooked, or that he will lose the opportunity to obtain an independent opinion on whether it is wise for him to plead guilty.
name: IOWA v. FELIPE EDGARDO TOVAR

opinion_summary: dismissal of a gerrymandering challenge to a congressional redistricting plan adopted by pennsylvania's general assembly is affirmed. these statewide claims are nonjusticiable.
name: RICHARD VIETH, NORMA JEAN VIETH, AND SUSAN FUREY v. ROBERT C. JUBELIRER, PRESIDENT OF THE PENNSYLVANIA SENATE, et al.

opinion_summary: sand and gravel are not valuable minerals reserved to the us in land grants issued under the pittman underground water act. sand and gravel are abundant throughout nevada, they have no intrinsic value, and they were commercially worthless when the act was passed in .
name: BEDROC LIMITED, LLC, AND WESTERN ELITE, INC. v. UNITED STATES et al.

opinion_summary: concerning a capital prisoner's habeas petition, the court found its decision in mills v. maryland,  u.s. , announced a new rule of constitutional law which did not fall under the teague exception, and therefore could not be applied retroactively by the habeas petitioner.
name: JEFFREY A. BEARD, SECRETARY, PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS, et al. v. GEORGE E. BANKS

opinion_summary: city's adult business license ordinance was found to meet the first amendment's requirements that such a licensing scheme ensure prompt judicial review of an administrative decision denying a license.
name: CITY OF LITTLETON, COLORADO v. Z. J. GIFTS D-4, L. L. C., A LIMITED LIABILITY COMPANY, DBA CHRISTAL'S

opinion_summary: a father did not have standing to challenge the under god portion of the pledge of allegiance as violating the establishment clause on behalf of his daughter, because he lacked next friend status under california law.
name: ELK GROVE UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT AND DAVID W. GORDON, SUPERINTENDENT v. MICHAEL A. NEWDOW et al.

opinion_summary: because the facts supporting the defendant's exceptionally harsh sentence were neither admitted by the defendant, nor found by a jury, the sentence violated defendant's sixth amendment right to trial by jury.
name: RALPH HOWARD BLAKELY, JR. v. WASHINGTON

opinion_summary: a timely application for attorney's fees per  u.s.c. section (d)may be amended after the -day filing period has run to cure an initial failure to allege that the government's position in the underlying litigation lacked substantial justification.
name: RANDALL C. SCARBOROUGH v. ANTHONY J. PRINCIPI, SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS

opinion_summary: as it applies to the class of cases implicating the fundamental right of access to the courts, title ii of the ada constitutes a valid exercise of congress' authority to enforce the fourteenth amendment's substantive guarantees.
name: TENNESSEE v. GEORGE LANE et al.

opinion_summary: title ix's private right of action encompasses claims of retaliation against an individual because he has complained about sex discrimination.
name: RODERICK JACKSON v. BIRMINGHAM BOARD OF EDUCATION

opinion_summary: the bipartisan campaign reform act of 's two principal, complementary features - congress's effort to plug the soft-money loophole and its regulation of electioneering communications - must be upheld in the main.
name: MITCH MCCONNELL, UNITED STATES SENATOR, et al. v. FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION, et al.

opinion_summary: a state court considered the proper factors and reached a reasonable conclusion that minor defendant was not in custody for miranda purposes during his police interview. the district court's decision granting habeas relief under aedpa is reversed.
name: MICHAEL YARBOROUGH, WARDEN v. MICHAEL ALVARADO

opinion_summary: a party's postfiling change in citizenship cannot cure a lack of subject-matter jurisdiction that existed at the time of filing in a diversity action.
name: GRUPO DATAFLUX v. ATLAS GLOBAL GROUP, L. P., et al.

opinion_summary: removal and disassembly of a vehicle's gas tank in the course of an international border inspection does not require reasonable suspicion. the interference with a motorist's possessory interest in his gas tank is justified by the government's paramount interest in preventing the entry of unwanted persons and effects.
name: UNITED STATES v. MANUEL FLORES-MONTANO

opinion_summary: tax injunction act did not bar plaintiffs' challenge to a state tax law providing for credits for payments made to school tuition organizations that provided scholarships to private school students, which plaintiffs challenged as violating the establishment clause.
name: J. ELLIOTT HIBBS, DIRECTOR, ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE v. KATHLEEN M. WINN et al.

opinion_summary: a section  vote dilution violation under the voting rights act,  u.s.c. section  is not an independent reason to deny section  preclearance. any diminution of a minority group's effective exercise of the electoral franchise violates section  only if the state cannot show that the gains in the plan as a whole offset the loss in a particular district.
name: GEORGIA v. JOHN ASHCROFT, ATTORNEY GENERAL, et al.

opinion_summary: the court declines to decide whether the actual innocence exception extends to noncapital sentencing errors. when faced with allegations of actual innocence, whether of the sentence or of the crime charged, a federal court must first address all nondefaulted claims for comparable relief and other grounds for cause to excuse the procedural default.
name: DOUG DRETKE, DIRECTOR, TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE, CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTIONS DIVISION v. MICHAEL WAYNE HALEY

opinion_summary: plaintiff's state causes of action, alleging hmo's failure to exercise ordinary care for the plaintiff's health by failing to cover the cost of certain medical services, was completely preempted by erisa section , and removable to federal court.
name: AETNA HEALTH INC., FKA AETNA U.S. HEALTHCARE INC. AND AETNA U.S. HEALTHCARE OF NORTH TEXAS INC. v. JUAN DAVILA

opinion_summary: a national park service regulation, purporting to render the contract disputes act of  inapplicable to contracts entered into by concessioners doing business in national parks, is a general policy statement. a challenge to that regulation is not yet ripe for judicial resolution, for lack of a hardship showing.
name: NATIONAL PARK HOSPITALITY ASSOCIATION v. DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR et al.

opinion_summary: a state law school's narrowly tailored use of race in admissions decisions, to further a compelling state interest in obtaining the educational benefits that flow from a diverse student body, is not prohibited by the equal protection clause, title vi, or  u.s.c. section .
name: BARBARA GRUTTER v. LEE BOLLINGER et al.

opinion_summary: u.s.c. section (d), requiring that a state statute of limitations be tolled for the period during which a cause of action had previously been pending in federal court, does not exceed congress's enumerated powers and is constitutional as applied to claims brought against a state's political subdivisions.
name: SUSAN JINKS v. RICHLAND COUNTY, SOUTH CAROLINA

opinion_summary: in appeals arising from agent orange exposure, judgment as to two respondents is vacated and remanded for further consideration in light of syngenta crop prot., inc. v. henson,  u.s.  (), but judgment as to other respondents is affirmed by an equally divided court.
name: DOW CHEMICAL COMPANY, et al. v. DANIEL RAYMOND STEPHENSON et al.

opinion_summary: an indian tribe did not qualify as a person who may sue under  u.s.c. section , under the circumstances, in an action asserting sovereign immunity from state court processes arising from a county investigation into alleged off-reservation crimes.
name: INYO COUNTY, CALIFORNIA, et al. v. PAIUTE-SHOSHONE INDIANS OF THE BISHOP COMMUNITY OF THE BISHOP COLONY et al.

opinion_summary: a louisiana public service commission order impermissibly traps costs that have been allocated in a ferc tariff, thus the order is subject to federal pre-emption.
name: ENTERGY LOUISIANA, INC. v. LOUISIANA PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION et al.

opinion_summary: an action filed in state court, to recover damages from a national bank for allegedly charging excessive interest in violation of both the common law usury doctrine and an alabama usury statute, arose only under federal law and could therefore be removed under  u.s.c. section .
name: BENEFICIAL NATIONAL BANK, et al. v. MARIE ANDERSON et al.

opinion_summary: an objective review of the performance by a criminal defendant's counsel in a capital case shows that the client's sixth amendment rights were violated by counsel's failure to conduct a reasonable investigation of the defendant's social history and mitigating factors.
name: KEVIN WIGGINS v. SEWALL SMITH, WARDEN, et al.

opinion_summary: a fair labor standards act provision stating that suit may be maintained. . .in any federal or state court of competent jurisdiction,  u.s.c. section (b), does not bar removal of a suit from state to federal court.
name: PHILLIP T. BREUER v. JIM'S CONCRETE OF BREVARD, INC.

opinion_summary: public libraries' use of internet filtering software does not violate their patrons' first amendment rights, thus the children's internet protection act (cipa) does not induce libraries to violate the constitution. cipa does not impose an unconstitutional condition on libraries receiving federal funding.
name: UNITED STATES, et al. v. AMERICAN LIBRARY ASSOCIATION, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: the trespass policy in place at a low-income housing development owned by a political subdivision is not facially invalid under the first amendment overbreadth doctrine, as ) the policy does not prohibit a substantial amount of protected speech in relation to legitimate applications, and ) rules apply to all person's entering the development, not just those seeking to engage in expression.
name: VIRGINIA v. KEVIN LAMONT HICKS

opinion_summary: application of the direct contribution prohibition,  u.s.c. section b, to non-profit advocacy corporations is consistent with the first amendment.
name: FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION v. CHRISTINE BEAUMONT et al.

opinion_summary: the full faith and credit clause (u.s. const. art. iv, section ) does not require nevada to give full faith and credit to california's statutes providing its tax collection agency with immunity from suit.
name: FRANCHISE TAX BOARD OF CALIFORNIA v. GILBERT P. HYATT, et al.

opinion_summary: the phrase origin of goods refers to the producer of tangible goods that are offered for sale, and not to the author of any idea, concept, or communication embodied in those goods, thus section  of the lanham act does not prevent the unaccredited copying of an uncopyrighted work.
name: DASTAR CORPORATION v. TWENTIETH CENTURY FOX FILM CORPORATION et al.

opinion_summary: the working owner of a business may qualify as a participant in a pension plan covered by erisa. if the plan covers one or more employees other than the business owner and his or her spouse, the working owner may participate on equal terms with other plan participants; such a working owner qualifies for the protections erisa affords plan participants and is governed by the rights and remedies erisa specifies. remanded with instructions regarding issue of loan repayments.
name: RAYMOND B. YATES, M.D., P.C. PROFIT SHARING PLAN, AND RAYMOND B. YATES, TRUSTEE v. WILLIAM T. HENDON, TRUSTEE

opinion_summary: erisa does not require plan administrators making disability determinations to accord special deference to the opinions of treating physicians, over other evidence relevant to the claimant's medical condition.
name: THE BLACK & DECKER DISABILITY PLAN v. KENNETH L. NORD

opinion_summary: in a case in which the defendant challenges search warrant, the ninth circuit's holding that there was no justification for forcible entry is reversed as the officers' -to--second wait before forcible entry satisfied the fourth amendment.
name: UNITED STATES v. LASHAWN LOWELL BANKS

opinion_summary: the manner in which a university uses racial preferences in undergraduate admissions is not narrowly tailored to achieve an asserted compelling state interest in diversity, and violates the equal protection clause, title vi, and  u.s.c. section .
name: JENNIFER GRATZ AND PATRICK HAMACHER v. LEE BOLLINGER et al.

opinion_summary: michigan supreme court's finding, that a judge's comments were not sufficiently final to terminate jeopardy, was not contrary to or an unreasonable application of clearly established u.s. supreme court precedent. federal circuit court erred in reviewing double jeopardy issue de novo, and finding that habeas relief was warranted.
name: JANETTE PRICE, WARDEN v. DUYONN ANDRE VINCENT

opinion_summary: where a criminal defendant was arrested without probable cause prior to his being questioned by police, his subsequent confession must be suppressed where the state failed to allege any meaningful intervening event between the illegal arrest and the confession.
name: ROBERT KAUPP v. TEXAS

opinion_summary: in an anti-trust case, usc section (a) authorizes, but does not require a district court to compel discovery requested by an adverse party to be used in a case brought before the directorate-general of the commission of european communities.
name: INTEL CORPORATION v. ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES, INC.

opinion_summary: this suit, brought under the clean water act and alleging that the removal of phosphorus-laden water from the c- canal into the wca- wetland requires a permit per the act's national pollutant discharge elimination system, is remanded for further proceedings regarding whether c- and wca- are meaningfully distinct water bodies.
name: SOUTH FLORIDA WATER MANAGEMENT DISTRICT v. MICCOSUKEE TRIBE OF INDIANS et al.

opinion_summary: enforcement of a consent decree that springs from a federal dispute and that furthers the objectives of federal law does not violate the eleventh amendment.
name: LINDA FREW, ON BEHALF OF HER DAUGHTER, CARLA FREW, et al. v. ALBERT HAWKINS, COMMISSIONER, TEXAS HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES COMMISSION, et al.

opinion_summary: the absence of an interrogation did not foreclose the accused's claim that jailhouse statements should have been suppressed as fruits of the statements taken from him at his home.
name: JOHN J. FELLERS v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: an arbitrator must determine whether contracts between a commercial lender and its customers, containing a clause providing for arbitration of all contract-related disputed, forbid class arbitration under south carolina law.
name: GREEN TREE FINANCIAL CORP., NKA CONSECO FINANCE CORP. v. LYNN W. BAZZLE et al., IN A REPRESENTATIVE CAPACITY ON BEHALF OF A CLASS AND FOR ALL OTHERS SIMILARLY SITUATED, et al.

opinion_summary: the clean air act authorizes defendant to stop construction of a major pollutant emitting facility permitted by a state authority when it finds that the authority's best available control technology determination is unreasonable in light of  u.s.c. section ()'s prescribed guides.
name: ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION v. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY et al.

opinion_summary: a federal court cannot recharacterize a pro se litigant's motion as a first section  motion unless it first informs the litigant of its intent to recharacterize, warns the litigant that this recharacterization means that any subsequent section  motion will be subject to the restrictions on second or successive motions, and provides the litigant an opportunity to withdraw the motion or to amend it so that it contains all the section  claims he believes he has.
name: HERNAN O'RYAN CASTRO v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: direct evidence of discrimination is not required for a plaintiff to obtain a mixed-motive jury instruction under title vii of the civil rights act of .
name: DESERT PALACE, INC., DBA CAESARS PALACE HOTEL & CASINO v. CATHARINA F. COSTA

opinion_summary: a class action alleging breach of an incumbent local exchange carrier's duty, per the telecommunications act of , to share its network with competitors does not state a claim under sherman act section . the activity complained of does not violate pre-existing antitrust standards, and the  act does not amend these standards; where there is a regulatory structure to deter and remedy anticompetitive harm, antitrust enforcement will tend to provide little additional benefit.
name: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS INC. v. LAW OFFICES OF CURTIS V TRINKO, LLP

opinion_summary: under the expanded power of magistrate judges authorized by the federal magistrate act of , consent to a magistrate judge's designation can be inferred from a party's conduct during litigation, such as through a general appearance before a magistrate after having been told of the right to appear before a district judge.
name: JOSEPH C. ROELL, PETRA GARIBAY, AND JAMES REAGAN v. JON MICHAEL WITHROW

opinion_summary: bankruptcy code section (a)() does not authorize compensation awards to debtors' attorneys from estate funds, unless they are employed as authorized by section . to be paid from estate funds under section (a)() in a chapter  case, the attorney must be employed by the trustee and approved by the court.
name: JOHN M. LAMIE v. UNITED STATES TRUSTEE

opinion_summary: iowa's differential tax rate, distinguishing between adjusted revenues from slot machines at racetracks and revenues from riverboat slot machines, does not violate the equal protection clause under a rational basis analysis.
name: MICHAEL FITZGERALD, TREASURER OF IOWA v. RACING ASSOCIATION OF CENTRAL IOWA et al.

opinion_summary: california's holocaust victim insurance relief act of , requiring any insurer doing business in that state to disclose information about certain policies sold in europe between  and , interferes with the president's conduct of the nation's foreign policy and is therefore preempted.
name: AMERICAN INSURANCE ASSOCIATION, et al. v. JOHN GARAMENDI, INSURANCE COMMISSIONER, STATE OF CALIFORNIA

opinion_summary: the ninth circuit improperly applied a disparate-impact analysis to plaintiff's disparate-treatment claim and improperly focused on factors that pertain only to disparate-impact claims, and thus ignored the fact that defendant's no-hire policy is a quintessential legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason for refusing to rehire an employee who was terminated for violating workplace conduct rules.
name: RAYTHEON COMPANY v. JOEL HERNANDEZ

opinion_summary: the third circuit is reversed where it unreasonably construed  u.s.c. section (d)()(a) to mean that the ability to perform prior work disqualifies from benefits only if it is substantial gainful work which exists in the national economy.
name: JO ANNE B. BARNHART, COMMISSIONER OF SOCIAL SECURITY v. PAULINE THOMAS

opinion_summary: finding cocaine in the back armrest when defendant was a front-seat passenger in a car being driven by its owner was sufficient to establish probable cause for an arrest for possession, thus defendant's arrest did not contravene the fourth and fourteenth amendments.
name: MARYLAND v. JOSEPH JERMAINE PRINGLE

opinion_summary: the search of plaintiffs' ranch was clearly unreasonable under the fourth amendment. the warrant was plainly invalid, failing to describe with particularity the items to be seized; because it did not describe these items at all, the search was presumptively unreasonable; defendant, who prepared and executed the warrant, is not entitled to qualified immunity because no reasonable officer could believe such a warrant to be valid.
name: JEFF GROH v. JOSEPH R. RAMIREZ et al.

opinion_summary: a debtor forfeits the right to challenge a creditor's objection to discharge as untimely under federal rule of bankruptcy procedure  if the debtor does not raise that rule's time limitation before the bankruptcy court reaches the merits of the creditor's objection to discharge.
name: ANDREW J. KONTRICK v. ROBERT A. RYAN

opinion_summary: when police or prosecutors conceal significant exculpatory or impeaching material in the state's possession, e.g., by withholding evidence that would have allowed a defendant to discredit essential prosecution witnesses, it is ordinarily incumbent on the state to set the record straight. the fifth circuit erred in dismissing death row inmate's brady claim with respect to one such witness, and in denying him a certificate of appealability with respect to another.
name: DELMA BANKS, JR. v. DOUG DRETKE, DIRECTOR, TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE, CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTIONS DIVISION

opinion_summary: regulation z, which interprets the truth in lending act's definition of finance charge to exclude charges for exceeding a credit limit, is not an unreasonable interpretation of  u.s.c. section .
name: HOUSEHOLD CREDIT SERVICES, INC. AND MBNA AMERICA BANK, N. A. v. SHARON R. PFENNIG

opinion_summary: in failing to determine whether the common pocketknife exception to florida's definition of a weapon encompassed petitioner's pocketknife at the time his conviction became final, the florida supreme court contradicted fiore v. white,  u.s.  ().
name: CLYDE TIMOTHY BUNKLEY v. FLORIDA

opinion_summary: erisa section (g) prohibits a pension plan amendment that expands the definition of postretirement employment that would trigger the suspension of early retirement benefits already accrued.
name: CENTRAL LABORERS' PENSION FUND v. THOMAS E. HEINZ et al.

opinion_summary: court of appeal's dismissal of prisoner's section  action is reversed where the rule in heck v. humphrey,  u. s.  (), which requires prisoners to resort to state litigation and federal habeas before section , does not apply here.
name: SHAKUR MUHAMMAD, AKA JOHN E. MEASE v. MARK CLOSE

opinion_summary: the fact that prison regulations limiting visitation bear a rational relation to legitimate penological interests suffices to sustain them, regardless of whether prisoners have a constitutional right of association that has survived incarceration.
name: WILLIAM OVERTON, DIRECTOR, MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS, et al. v. MICHELLE BAZZETTA et al.

opinion_summary: admission of a testimonial statement made by defendant's wife during police interrogation violated the confrontation clause. where testimonial statements are at issue, the only indicium of reliability sufficient to satisfy constitutional demands is confrontation.
name: MICHAEL D. CRAWFORD v. WASHINGTON

opinion_summary: the foia recognizes surviving family members' right to personal privacy with respect to their close relative's death-scene images. the privacy interest of vincent foster's family is protected by exemption (c), and outweighs the public interest in disclosure; the requester failed to produce evidence warranting a belief that responsible officials might have acted negligently or otherwise improperly in performing their duties.
name: NATIONAL ARCHIVES AND RECORDS ADMINISTRATION v. ALLAN J. FAVISH et al.

opinion_summary: a state prisoner ordinarily does not fairly present a federal claim to a state court if that court must read beyond a petition, a brief, or similar papers to find material, such as a lower court opinion in the case, that will alert it to the presence of such a claim. accordingly, the prisoner seeking habeas relief in the instant case failed to exhaust available state rememdies.
name: GEORGE H. BALDWIN v. MICHAEL REESE

opinion_summary: the bureau of land management's alleged failure to protect state lands from environmental damage caused by off-road vehicles was not remediable under the administrative procedure act.
name: GALE NORTON, SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR, et al. v. SOUTHERN UTAH WILDERNESS ALLIANCE et al.

opinion_summary: the due process and equal protection clauses require the appointment of counsel for defendants, convicted on their pleas, who seek access to first-tier review in the michigan court of appeals.
name: ANTONIO DWAYNE HALBERT v. MICHIGAN

opinion_summary: the court lacked jurisdiction over plaintiff's habeas petition, because the u. s. secretary of state, against whom the petition was brought, was not the immediate custodian of plaintiff's person, and therefore was not the proper respondent.
name: DONALD H. RUMSFELD, SECRETARY OF DEFENSE v. JOSE PADILLA AND DONNA R. NEWMAN, AS NEXT FRIEND OF JOSE PADILLA

opinion_summary: the state court did not err when it found that, considering the instructions on voluntary manslaughter and imperfect self-defense in their entirety, there was no reasonable likelihood the jury was misled by the erroneous imminent-peril instruction.
name: RAYMOND L. MIDDLETON, WARDEN v. SALLY MARIE MCNEIL

opinion_summary: the grant of habeas relief to defendant is reversed where the ninth circuit's decision was contrary to the limits on federal habeas review imposed by the antiterrorism and effective death penalty act.
name: JILL L. BROWN, WARDEN v. WILLIAM CHARLES PAYTON

opinion_summary: because congress recognizes the tribes' criminal jurisdiction over nonmember indians, the spirit lake tribe acted in its capacity as a sovereign authority when it prosecuted defendant, thus the double jeopardy clause does not prohibit the federal government from prosecuting him for a discrete federal offense.
name: UNITED STATES v. BILLY JO LARA

opinion_summary: although the disparate-impact theory of recovery, for cases brought under title vii of the civil rights act of , is cognizable under the age discrimination in employment act of , the disparate-impact theory's scope is narrower under the adea than under title vii.
name: AZEL P. SMITH, et al. v. CITY OF JACKSON, MISSISSIPPI, et al.

opinion_summary: generic advertising to promote beef and beef products, financed through assessments on the sale of cattle, is the government's own speech and is not susceptible to a first amendment compelled-subsidy challenge.
name: MIKE JOHANNS, SECRETARY OF AGRICULTURE, et al., v. LIVESTOCK MARKETING ASSOCIATION et al.

opinion_summary: concerning a habeas petition, the sixth circuit erred in holding that the state court's application of strickland was unreasonable on evidence not properly before the state court, and in finding that the district court wrongly assessed prejudice under a preponderance standard, rather than a reasonable probability standard.
name: FLORA HOLLAND, WARDEN v. JESSIE L. JACKSON

opinion_summary: a flat $ fee that michigan charges trucks engaging in intrastate commercial hauling does not violate the dormant commerce clause.
name: AMERICAN TRUCKING ASSOCIATIONS, INC. AND USF HOLLAND, INC. v. MICHIGAN PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION et al.

opinion_summary: a michigan law which imposes an annual fee of $. upon each michigan license-plated truck that is operating entirely in interstate commerce is not preempted by  u.s.c. section (b) since the fee requirement is not the kind of state registration requirement to which the federal statute refers.
name: MID-CON FREIGHT SYSTEMS, INC., et al. v. MICHIGAN PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION, et al.

opinion_summary: the use of patented compounds in preclinical studies is protected under  u.s.c. section (e)() as long as there is a reasonable basis to believe that the compound tested could be the subject of an fda submission and the experiments will produce the types of information relevant to a new drug application.
name: MERCK KGAA v. INTEGRA LIFESCIENCES I, LTD., et al.

opinion_summary: during a continuous workday, any walking time that occurs after the beginning of the employee-s first principal activity, such as the donning of protective gear, and before the end of the employee-s last principal activity is compensable under the fair labor standards act (flsa); however, the time employees spend waiting to don the first piece of protective gear that marks the beginning of the continuous workday is excluded from flsa coverage.
name: IBP, INC. v. GABRIEL ALVAREZ, INDIVIDUALLY AND ON BEHALF OF ALL OTHERS SIMILARLY SITUATED, et al.

opinion_summary: conviction for conspiracy to commit money laundering, in violation of  u.s.c. section (h), does not require proof of an overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy.
name: DAVID WHITFIELD v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: the foreign sovereign immunities act applies retroactively to actions of foreign states that occurred before the fsia's  enactment. the expropriation exception to the act would allow a private party to recover paintings from austria, which were seized by nazis in .
name: REPUBLIC OF AUSTRIA et al. v. ALTMANN

opinion_summary: title iii of the americans with disabilities act of  is applicable to foreign-flag cruise ships in united states waters except where the statute regulates a vessel's internal affairs.
name: DOUGLAS SPECTOR, et al. v. NORWEGIAN CRUISE LINE LTD.

opinion_summary: plaintiffs' suit, asserting estoppel and due process claims for the cia's alleged failure to provide them with financial assistance it had promised in return for their espionage services during the cold war, is barred by totten v. us,  u.s.  (), which prohibits suits against the government based on covert espionage agreements.
name: GEORGE J. TENET, INDIVIDUALLY, PORTER J. GOSS, DIRECTOR OF CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AND DIRECTOR OF THE CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY, AND UNITED STATES v. JOHN DOE, ET UX.

opinion_summary: congress's commerce clause authority includes the power to prohibit the local cultivation and use of marijuana in compliance with california law.
name: ALBERTO R. GONZALES, ATTORNEY GENERAL, et al. v. ANGEL MCCLARY RAICH et al.

opinion_summary: plaintiff's challenge to a permanent injunction, prohibiting him from picketing and orally uttering statements about johnnie cochran, who died after the issuance of the injunction, is not moot where cochran's widow can be substituted as a defendant.
name: ULYSSES TORY, et al. v. JOHNNIE L. COCHRAN, JR.

opinion_summary: the establishment clause of the first amendment allows the display of a monument inscribed with the ten commandments on the texas state capitol grounds.
name: THOMAS VAN ORDEN v. RICK PERRY, IN HIS OFFICIAL CAPACITY AS GOVERNOR OF TEXAS AND CHAIRMAN, STATE PRESERVATION BOARD, et al.

opinion_summary: section uu of the reclamation reform act does not waive the united states' sovereign immunity from breach of contract suits.
name: FRANCIS A. ORFF, et al. v. UNITED STATES et al.

opinion_summary: an individual may not enforce the limitations on local zoning authority, set forth in section (c)() of the communications act, through an action under  u.s.c. section .
name: CITY OF RANCHO PALOS VERDES, CALIFORNIA, et al. v. MARK J. ABRAMS

opinion_summary: the termination of defendant's employment as a police officer, for selling videotapes of himself engaging in sexually explicit acts, does not violate his first and fourteenth amendment rights to freedom of speech.
name: CITY OF SAN DIEGO, CALIFORNIA et al. v. JOHN ROE

opinion_summary: to obtain relief for an unpreserved frcp rule  failing, a defendant must show a reasonable probability that but for the error, he would not have plead guilty.
name: UNITED STATES v. CARLOS DOMINGUEZ BENITEZ

opinion_summary: a county's manifest objective may be dispositive for determining whether a display of the ten commandments in courthouses violates the establishment clause.
name: MCCREARY COUNTY, KENTUCKY, et al. v. AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION OF KENTUCKY et al.

opinion_summary: the rooker-feldman doctrine is confined to cases brought by state-court losers complaining of injuries caused by state-court judgments rendered before the district court proceedings commenced and inviting district court review and rejection of those judgments.
name: EXXON MOBIL CORPORATION, EXXON CHEMICAL ARABIA, INC., AND MOBIL YANBU PETROCHEMICAL COMPANY, INC. v. SAUDI BASIC INDUSTRIES CORPORATION

opinion_summary: the tax court may not exclude from the record on appeal tax court rule (b) reports submitted by special trial judges.
name: CLAUDE M. BALLARD, ET UX. v. COMMISSIONER OF INTERNAL REVENUE

opinion_summary: the court upheld a preliminary injunction barring the enforcement of the child online pornography act, because the statute likely violates the first amendment.
name: JOHN D. ASHCROFT, ATTORNEY GENERAL v. AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION et al.

opinion_summary: a district court is not required to warn a pro se plaintiff bringing a habeas petition that it could not consider motions to stay unless plaintiff dismissed unexhausted claims, or that if he chose to dismiss the claims, they would be time-barred if raised in the future.
name: CHERYL K. PLILER, WARDEN v. RICHARD HERMAN FORD

opinion_summary: state prisoners may challenge the constitutionality of state parole procedures under a section  action for declaratory and injunctive relief; they are not required to seek relief exclusively under the federal habeas corpus statutes.
name: REGINALD A. WILKINSON, DIRECTOR, OHIO DEPARTMENT OF REHABILITATION AND CORRECTION, et al. v. WILLIAM DWIGHT DOTSON, et al.
