opinion_summary: held that a private entity operating public access cable tv channels was not subject to first amendment constraints on its editorial discretion. the producers of a controversial documentary film contended that the nonprofit corporation running the public access channels was a state actor because it was exercising a function traditionally exclusively reserved to the state, and therefore was subject to suit for violating their free speech rights. however, the u.s. supreme court disagreed. justice kavanaugh delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: MANHATTAN COMMUNITY ACCESS CORP. v. HALLECK

opinion_summary: addressed whether the telephone consumer protection act prohibits unsolicited fax advertisements that promote free goods, such as no-cost magazine subscriptions and catalogs. the specific issue here had to do with whether the district court was required to adopt the federal communications commission's interpretation of the statute. the u.s. supreme court stated that it found the question difficult to answer, and remanded with directions for the lower courts to resolve two preliminary issues. justice breyer delivered the court's opinion.
name: PDR NETWORK, LLC v. CARLTON & HARRIS CHIROPRACTIC INC.,

opinion_summary: held that a maryland public monument in the shape of a -foot tall latin cross did not violate the establishment clause. a humanist group and others argued that the memorial to soldiers who died in world war i must be removed because of the crucifix shape. the u.s. supreme court disagreed. justice alito announced the judgment of the court; however, only certain portions of his opinion received support from a majority of the justices.
name: AMERICAN LEGION v. AMERICAN HUMANIST ASSOCIATION

opinion_summary: reversing an eleventh circuit determination that a man convicted of murdering a police officer  years ago who had since suffered strokes and claimed not to remember the crime could not be executed because he retained the mental capacity to understand that he was being executed for a crime.
name: DUNN v. MADISON

opinion_summary: declaring a writ of certiorari petition moot in the case of microsoft's attempt to avoid providing emails pursuant to a government warrant investigating the drug trade because a new warrant was issued under a new law that, unlike the old version, permitted the government to demand emails stored on overseas datacenters under trump's clarifying lawful overseas use of data act.
name: UNITED STATES v. MICROSOFT CORP.

opinion_summary: held that consumers could proceed with an antitrust lawsuit alleging that apple inc. used monopolistic power to overcharge for iphone apps. apple contended that the lawsuit was barred because the consumers were not direct purchasers within the meaning of the illinois brick case. however, the u.s. supreme court rejected apple's argument in a - decision, on review of a dismissal ruling. justice kavanaugh delivered the majority opinion, joined by the four liberal justices.
name: APPLE INC. v. PEPPER

opinion_summary: in a first amendment free speech case, the court ordered the judgment of the court of appeals vacated and the case remanded holding that probable cause does not bar a first amendment retaliation claim. plaintiff argued that he was a arrested because of a retaliation plan by the defendant-city for his outspoken criticism of the cities policies. the defendant city argued they had probable cause to arrest plaintiff because of his disruptive behavior at a city council meetings. the us supreme court held that plaintiff need not prove the absence of probable cause in order to maintain a first amendment claim for retaliatory arrest under  u.s.c section .
name: LOZMAN v. CITY OF RIVIERA BEACH, FLORIDA

opinion_summary: clarified when federal law will preempt a state law claim that a drug manufacturer failed to warn consumers of a drug's risks. held that this preemption question is one for a judge to decide, not a jury. also spelled out the &#;clear evidence&#; standard that applies in this context. justice breyer, joined by five justices, delivered the u.s. supreme court's majority opinion in this product liability lawsuit against a drugmaker.
name: MERCK SHARP & DOHME CORP. v. ALBRECHT

opinion_summary: reversing a court of appeals decision to treat a suit challenging the constitutionality of full restraints on in custody defendants in nonjury proceedings by the u.s. marshals service as a class like claim or functional class action because the suit had not proceeded as a class action and the resolution of the underlying criminal cases rendered the plaintiff's actions moot.
name: UNITED STATES v. SANCHEZ-GOMEZ

opinion_summary: this a maryland gerrymandering case, wherein a motion for preliminary injunction was denied by the district court. the us supreme court affirmed the decision holding that the district court did not abuse its discretion in denying a preliminary injunction in light of gill v. whitford, no. -, pending before the supreme court. the gill case was expected to shed light on critical questions at issue in the benisek case.
name: BENISEK v. LAMONE

opinion_summary: construed a provision of the federal arbitration act that excludes disputes involving certain transportation workers. the plaintiffs, interstate truck drivers, argued that their wage-hour lawsuit fell within the exclusion, and thus there was no basis to force them into arbitration despite the mandatory arbitration clause in their contract. agreeing, the supreme court also held that the faa's transportation worker exclusion covers independent contractors. justice gorsuch wrote the - opinion (justice kavanaugh took no part).
name: NEW PRIME INC. v. OLIVEIRA

opinion_summary: holding that tribal sovereign immunity does not apply to in rem suits in the case of the purchase of a  acre plot of land by a native american tribe that was sued in a quiet title action by a landowner who claimed an acre of the land by adverse possession and mutual acquiescence.
name: UPPER SKAGIT INDIAN TRIBE v. LUNDGREN

opinion_summary: held that west virginia unlawfully discriminated against a u.s. marshalls service retiree when it gave a generous pension tax benefit only to state or local retirees who served in law enforcement. the plaintiff relied on a federal statute that, broadly speaking, bars states from taxing the compensation of federal employees differently from state employees. in a unanimous opinion written by justice gorsuch, the u.s. supreme court agreed with him that west virginia's tax rule unlawfully disfavored federal retirees.
name: DAWSON v. STEAGER

opinion_summary: affirming the rejection of facial insufficiency arguments relating to a wiretap order used in the investigation of a drug distribution ring in kansas that contained a sentence purporting to authorize interception outside of the state and resulted in the interception of additional communications from a listening post in missouri, which evidence was subsequently not introduced, but did not render the rest o the wiretap order unlawful.
name: DAHDA v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: holding that a putative class member may not, in lieu of promptly joining an existing suit or promptly filing an individual claim, commence a class action anew beyond the time allowed by the applicable statute of limitations and reversing and remanding the ninth circuit's reversal of a district court dismissal of an untimely class complaint.
name: CHINA AGRITECH, INC. v. RESH

opinion_summary: reversed and remanded. under the illegal immigration reform and immigrant responsibility act of  non-permanent residents are subject to removal under certain circumstances. plaintiff, a native of brazil, came to the us in  and remained after his visa expired. he was stopped for a dui and was sent a notice to appear by the department of homeland security. the notice did not contain a date or time for the removal hearing. the plaintiff failed to appear and dhs ordered his removal. the supreme court ruled that the government must furnish the time and place information in order to enforce the removal.
name: PEREIRA v. SESSIONS, ATT'Y GEN.

opinion_summary: granting a petition for certiorari and reversing the judgment of the court of appeals that the shooting of a knife-wielding woman was a violation of the fourth amendment because the woman's failure to respond to police requests to drop the weapon and her proximity to a third party provided probable cause that she posed a threat of serious harm to the officers or others and it was not unconstitutionally unreasonable to prevent escape by the use of deadly force.
name: KISELA v. HUGHES

opinion_summary: vacated and remanded. sellers of goods and services are required to collect and remit sales taxes to the state, but if the seller does not have a physical presence in the state it does not collect such taxes under quill corp v. north dakota,  us . south dakota enacted a law to require out of state sellers to collect and pay sales tax. defendant filed suit alleging south dakotas act violated quill. the supreme court held that quill and national bellas hess v. department of revenue of ill,  us  are overruled and that a physical presence is no longer required.
name: SOUTH DAKOTA v. WAYFAIR

opinion_summary: reversing a district court determination that inferences which once allowed the presumption that collective-bargaining agreements vested retiree benefits for life could be used to characterize them as ambiguous, permitting the consultation of extrinsic evidence about lifetime vesting, because this approach did not square with the principles of contract law guiding such interpretations.
name: CNH INDUSTRIAL NV v. REESE

opinion_summary: reversed and remanded. the railroad retirement tax act of  was enacted to provide pensions to railroad workers at a time when many railroads were on the brink of insolvency. under the act, railroads paid a tax based on employee incomes, but no tax was paid on payments made to employees in kind. to modernize the pension fund, stock options were adopted. congress sought to tax the options. the supreme court held that employee stock options are not taxable under the act because they are not money remunerations.
name: WISCONSIN CENTRAL LTD. v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: held that members of the crow tribe retain a broad right under an  treaty to hunt on land that is now part of the bighorn national forest in wyoming. one issue was whether the treaty hunting rights expired when wyoming became a state. the u.s. supreme court, divided -, ruled favorably to the tribe. justice sotomayor delivered the majority opinion.
name: HERRERA v. WYOMING

opinion_summary: held that the armed career criminal act encompasses a robbery offense if an element is the use of force sufficient to overcome a victim's resistance. under this test, the defendant's conviction of robbery under florida law qualified as a predicate violent felony for a -year mandatory-minimum sentence. justice thomas wrote the - opinion, which distinguished johnson v. us,  u. s.  ().
name: STOKELING v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: in a federal sentencing case, the court affirmed the decision of the appellate court stating that the trial judge sufficiently demonstrated a reasoned basis for the sentence given. the court noted the simplicity of the case, the trial judge's awareness of the arguments, the consideration of relevant sentencing factors and the intuitive reason why the sentence was chosen, all of which fell within the scope of professional judgment of sentencing judges allowed by law.
name: CHAVEZ-MEZA v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: held that a copyright claimant may not commence an infringement suit until the copyright office registers the copyright. the plaintiff, a news organization that sued a news website for infringement, argued that the relevant date should be when the copyright office receives a completed application for registration, even if the register of copyrights has not yet acted on that application. the u.s. supreme court disagreed, in a unanimous opinion delivered by justice ginsburg.
name: FOURTH ESTATE PUBLIC BENEFIT CORP. v. WALL-STREET.COM

opinion_summary: affirming lower court determinations that petitioners who pleaded guilty to drug conspiracy charges were not qualified for sentence reductions where the sentencing commission had amended the guidelines to reduce base offense levels for certain drug offenses because their sentences were explicitly not based upon the guideline ranges in the first instance, but rather predicated on their mandatory minimums and their substantial assistance to the government.
name: KOONS v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: reversed in part, affirmed in part and cases remanded. in this gerrymandering case, the us supreme court found that the texas court erred in enjoining the use of districting maps adopted by the texas legislature in , stating that it was the challengers burden to show that the  legislature acted with discriminatory intent and it was not the  legislature obligation to show that it had cured the discriminatory intent.
name: ABBOTT v. PEREZ

opinion_summary: held that state and local government entities are covered by the age discrimination in employment act regardless of their size. in an age discrimination suit brought by two firefighters, a fire district argued that it was too small to qualify as an employer under the adea because it had fewer than  employees. disagreeing, the supreme court concluded that the adea's -employee coverage threshold is inapplicable to states and political subdivisions. justice ginsburg wrote the unanimous - opinion.
name: MOUNT LEMMON FIRE DISTRICT v. GUIDO

opinion_summary: granting a petition for writ of certiorari and vacating a court of appeals denial of a certificate of appealability relating to the decision of the district court to deny a motion to reopen federal habeas corpus proceedings in the case of a man convicted of murder and sentenced to death whose jury included a juror who later provided a sworn affidavit that indicated their prejudicial view of black people because the district court and appeals court denials, which rested on the ground that it was indisputable among reasonable jurists that having a racist on the jury did not prejudice the defendant.
name: THARPE v. SELLERS, WARDEN

opinion_summary: held that congress may lawfully delegate to the attorney general the authority to prescribe certain sex-offender registration rules. the dispute here involved the nondelegation doctrine, which bars congress from transferring its legislative power to another branch of government. justice kagan announced the court's judgment and delivered a plurality opinion.
name: GUNDY v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: held that a property owner whose property has been taken by a local government may go directly to federal court to assert a claim under the takings clause. overruled a  supreme court precedent (williamson county regional planning comm'n v. hamilton bank of johnson city), which had said that a property owner must first seek just compensation under state law in state court before bringing a federal takings claim under section . chief justice roberts delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: KNICK v. TOWNSHIP OF SCOTT, PENNSYLVANIA

opinion_summary: granting a petition for writ of certiorari in the case of a minor who sought, and was denied, an abortion while in the custody of the office of refugee resettlement because an abortion had been performed in the interim rendering the individual claim for injunctive relief moot.
name: AZAR v. GARZA

opinion_summary: revived a commercial timber plantation's challenge to the designation of its land as critical habitat for an endangered species of frog, which had not been spotted there for decades. held that an area is eligible for designation as critical habitat under a provision of the endangered species act only if it is habitat for the species. also held that the secretary of the interior's decision not to exclude an area from critical habitat is subject to judicial review. chief justice roberts wrote the unanimous - opinion, vacating the decision below and remanding for further proceedings.
name: WEYERHAEUSER COMPANY v. U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

opinion_summary: reversed and remanded. plaintiff alleges that when police officers visited her apartment in response to a noise complaint, they engaged in strange and abusive behavior before citing her for disorderly conduct and interfering with law enforcement. plaintiff also claims that the police told her to stop when she got on her knees and began praying. plaintiff filed a complaint alleging violations of her first and fourth amendment rights. the district court dismissed the complaint for failure to state a claim and the tenth circuit affirmed. the supreme court held that there is not enough information in the record to determine if there were violations of the first and fourth amendments and therefore reversed and remanded.
name: SAUSE v. BAUER

opinion_summary: held that the eighth amendment may permit executing a prisoner even if he cannot remember committing his crime, but it may forbid execution if his dementia prevents him from comprehending why he is being put to death. a death row inmate in alabama argued that his memory loss and dementia entitled him to a stay of execution. in a - decision, the u.s. supreme court clarified the law on these matters and remanded to the state court for further proceedings, in an opinion delivered by justice kagan. justice kavanaugh took no part in the decision.
name: MADISON v. ALABAMA

opinion_summary: interpreted the meaning of burglary in the armed career criminal act. held that the statutory term includes burglary of a structure or vehicle that has been adapted or is customarily used for overnight accommodation. the act requires an enhanced sentence for offenders who have at least three previous convictions for certain violent or drug-related felonies, and specifically includes burglary as one of those prior felonies. justice breyer wrote the unanimous opinion.
name: UNITED STATES v. STITT

opinion_summary: held that the social security act's  percent cap on attorney fees applies only to fees for court representation. the lower court erroneously applied the cap to the aggregate fees awarded for representation before both the agency and the court. justice thomas wrote the unanimous opinion, which resolved a circuit split regarding the fees that attorneys may charge social security claimants for representation. the decision relied on the plain meaning of the statute.
name: CULBERTSON v. BERRYHILL

opinion_summary: addressed the question of when burglary qualifies as a predicate offense for enhanced sentencing under the armed career criminal act. more specifically, the narrow issue concerned what it means to remain in a building or structure with intent to commit a crime. ultimately, held that violation of michigan's third-degree home-invasion statute qualified as a predicate offense. justice kavanaugh delivered the opinion for a unanimous court.
name: QUARLES v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: granting a petition for writ of certiorari, vacating the order of the court of appeals, and remanding a case involving the documentation provided relating to the government's attempts to rescind the program known as deferred action for childhood arrivals (daca) because a district court order demanding the production of all related materials was at least partly overbroad.
name: in re UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: held that a death row inmate's execution by lethal injection would not subject him to constitutionally impermissible suffering, even if his unusual health issues meant that he would experience particularly excruciating pain. the inmate contended that his medical condition meant missouri's legal injection protocol was unconstitutional as applied to him. in a - decision, the u.s. supreme court held that he failed to satisfy the baze-glossip test. justice gorsuch delivered the majority opinion.
name: BUCKLEW v. PRECYTHE

opinion_summary: addressed whether a convicted criminal's period of supervised release is tolled -- in effect, paused -- during pretrial detention for a new criminal offense. held that tolling occurs if certain conditions are met. justice thomas delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: MONT v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: held that the national park service lacked authority to regulate boating on alaska's nation river. a moose hunter contended that the park service could not ban him from using a hovercraft on a portion of the river that crossed a national preserve. ruling in his favor, the u.s. supreme court explained that while the park service normally may establish rules for boating on waters within national parks, the alaska national interest lands conservation act creates an alaska-specific exception. justice kagan delivered the unanimous opinion.
name: STURGEON v. FROST

opinion_summary: interpreted a federal statute that prohibits felons and certain other individuals from knowingly possessing firearms. held that the government must prove both that the defendant knew he possessed a firearm and that he knew he belonged to the relevant category of persons barred from possessing a firearm. justice breyer delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: REHAIF v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: addressed whether the state of mississippi's peremptory strike of a particular black prospective juror was motivated by discriminatory intent. justice kavanaugh, who delivered the opinion of the - court, explicitly stated that the decision broke no new legal ground but rather simply reinforced the batson decision, in this case involving a man's sixth murder trial (the other five had ended in hung juries or else been reversed on appeal).
name: FLOWERS v. MISSISSIPPI

opinion_summary: remanded a class action settlement case for the courts below to address the named plaintiffs' standing to sue, in light of spokeo inc. v. robins,  u.s. __ (). issued a per curiam opinion, in this consumer suit against an internet company.
name: FRANK v. GAOS

opinion_summary: reversed and remanded. president trump sought to deny foreign nationals from specific countries, chad, iran, iraq, libya, north korea, syria venezuela, and yemen entry into the us. the state of hawaii brought suit to block the ban, which they alleged was largely based on religious grounds. the us supreme court has now held that the president has exercised a lawfully granted power under  usc section  and (a) to enforce the ban.
name: TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF U.S. v. HAWAII

opinion_summary: in the case of the challenge to the trump administration's travel ban and the associated injunction, the court granted certiorari and consolidation of the executive order's challenges, granting a stay of the preliminary injunctions, to the extent that the injunctions prevent enforcement with respect to foreign nationals who lack any bona-fide relationship with a person or entity in the united states.
name: TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF U.S. v. HAWAII

opinion_summary: held that parties do not consent to classwide arbitration if the agreement is ambiguous on that point. an employer sought to block an employee from proceeding with a proposed class action lawsuit and instead force his claims into individual arbitration. the u.s. supreme court agreed that the employer had the right to do this, because the arbitration agreement was ambiguous about the availability of classwide arbitration. chief justice roberts delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: LAMPS PLUS INC. v. VARELA

opinion_summary: vacated and remanded. plaintiff is a vietnam veteran who sought disability benefits from the veterans administration for post-traumatic stress. the va eventually granted benefits but only from the motion to re-open his case and not from the date of the original application. court of appeals affirmed the ruling citing the deference doctrine. the us supreme court vacated the judgment and remanded to have the lower court determine if the deference doctrine applied in this case.
name: KISOR v. WILKIE

opinion_summary: held that a mariner may not recover punitive damages on a claim that he was injured as a result of the unseaworthy condition of the vessel. after a hatch blew open and injured his hand, the deckhand filed suit under federal maritime law and sought punitive damages, among other things. however, the u.s. supreme court concluded that punitive damages are unavailable in unseaworthiness actions. justice alito delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: THE DUTRA GROUP v. BATTERTON

opinion_summary: held that the ninth circuit should not have counted the vote of a circuit judge who died before the decision was issued, because deceased federal judges cannot exercise judicial power after their death. the judge had passed away  days before the issuance of his en banc majority opinion in this equal pay act case, and his vote made a difference in the outcome. based on this error, the u.s. supreme court vacated and remanded in a per curiam opinion.
name: YOVINO v. RIZO

opinion_summary: in a case alleging racial gerrymandering, held that the virginia house of delegates lacked standing to appeal the invalidation of virginia's  redistricting plan. as a single chamber of a bicameral legislature, the house had no standing to appeal a three-judge federal district court's redistricting ruling separately from the state of which it is a part. justice ginsburg delivered the opinion of the - court, joined by justices thomas, sotomayor, kagan and gorsuch.
name: VIRGINIA HOUSE OF DELEGATES v. BETHUNE-HILL

opinion_summary: struck down a statutory provision that prohibits the registration of immoral or scandalous trademarks. an entrepreneur who founded a new clothing line filed a first amendment challenge when the u.s. patent and trademark office refused to register his desired trademark fuct. the u.s. supreme court sided with him and invalidated a provision of the lanham act. justice kagan delivered the opinion of the court, in which five other justices joined.
name: IANCU v. BRUNETTI

opinion_summary: clarified the statute of limitations in qui tam lawsuits. justice thomas delivered the court's unanimous opinion in this case involving the false claims act.
name: COCHISE CONSULTANCY INC. v. U.S., EX REL. HUNT

opinion_summary: addressed what law applies on the outer continental shelf, holding that california wage-and-hour law was inapplicable to a worker on an offshore drilling platform. under the outer continental shelf lands act, if federal law addresses the relevant issue, state law is not adopted as surrogate federal law. justice thomas delivered the opinion for a unanimous court.
name: PARKER DRILLING MANAGEMENT SERVICES, LTD. v. NEWTON

opinion_summary: vacated and remanded. plaintiffs as voters in north carolina and maryland filed suit challenging congressional districting maps as unconstitutional partisan gerrymanders. the district court ruled in favor of plaintiffs. the us supreme court held that partisan gerrymandering claims present political questions that are beyond the reach of the federal courts.
name: RUCHO v. COMMON CAUSE

opinion_summary: affirmed in part. defendants were charged with hobbs act robbery and also charged under  u.s.c. sec. c which authorizes heightened penalties for using a weapon. the fifth circuit held that sec.  c  b is unconstitutionally vague because it did not provide a reliable way to determine which crimes would qualify for heightened penalties. the us supreme court agreed holding that  u.s.c. sec.  c  b is unconstitutional for vagueness and remanded the case.
name: UNITED STATES v. DAVIS

opinion_summary: held that a man convicted of murder had shown that he had an intellectual disability and thus was ineligible for the death penalty. in reaching a contrary conclusion, the texas state court impermissibly relied on &#;lay stereotypes of the intellectually disabled&#; -- just as it had a few years ago the first time this case came before the u.s. supreme court. the high court issued a per curiam opinion here, criticizing the texas court for not heeding its prior instructions. justices alito, thomas and gorsuch dissented.
name: MOORE v. TEXAS

opinion_summary: clarified the limits of a state's power to tax a trust. struck down a north carolina requirement that a trust must pay income tax to the state whenever the trust's beneficiaries live in the state -- regardless of whether the beneficiaries have received, can demand, or will ever receive a distribution of trust income. justice sotomayor delivered the opinion for a unanimous court, in this due process challenge brought by a family trust.
name: NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE v. THE KIMBERLEY RICE KAESTNER 1992 FAMILY TRUST

opinion_summary: reversed and remanded. defendants sought disclosure, through a foia request, of names and addresses of retail stores who participated in the national food stamp program. plaintiff refused to provide that information stating that substantive competitive harm would be caused. the district court disagreed with plaintiff and ordered disclosure. the us supreme court reversed and held that data provided under an assurance of privacy was an exemption to a foia request.
name: FOOD MARKETING INSTITUTE v. ARGUS LEADER MEDIA

opinion_summary: upheld an indiana law relating to the disposition of fetal remains by abortion providers. the seventh circuit had struck down the law, which altered the manner in which abortion providers may dispose of fetal remains; for instance, the law prevents incineration of fetal remains along with surgical byproducts. the u.s. supreme court concluded in a per curiam decision that the law passes rational basis review. only two justices dissented.
name: BOX v. PLANNED PARENTHOOD OF IND. & KY.

opinion_summary: clarified when the statute of limitations begins to run on a fabricated-evidence claim. held that the clock started when the criminal proceedings terminated in the defendant's favor -- that is, when he was acquitted at the end of his second trial. justice sotomayor delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: MCDONOUGH v. SMITH

opinion_summary: clarified the circumstances in which a court may hold a creditor in civil contempt for attempting to collect a debt that a bankruptcy discharge order has immunized from collection. held that there should be &#;no fair ground of doubt&#; that the order barred the creditor's conduct. justice breyer delivered the opinion for a unanimous court.
name: TAGGART v. LORENZEN

opinion_summary: held that title vii's charge-filing requirement is not jurisdictional and thus is subject to forfeiture if tardily asserted. the issue involved whether an employer waited too long to dispute that a discrimination plaintiff filed a proper complaint with the equal employment opportunity commission before initiating suit. justice ginsburg delivered the opinion for a unanimous court.
name: FORT BEND COUNTY, TEXAS v. DAVIS

opinion_summary: held that an ohio death row inmate should not have been granted habeas relief. his claim that he had an intellectual disability that constitutionally barred him from being executed should have been evaluated based solely on supreme court holdings that were clearly established at the relevant time. because the sixth circuit improperly relied on a subsequently decided case, moore v. texas () in assessing the intellectual disability issue, the high court vacated the habeas ruling and remanded in a per curiam opinion.
name: SHOOP v. HILL

opinion_summary: held that when a motorist suspected of drunk driving is unconscious and cannot be given a breath test, the exigent-circumstances doctrine generally permits a blood test without a warrant. justice alito announced the judgment of the court and delivered a plurality opinion, joined by three other justices. justice thomas concurring in the judgment.
name: MITCHELL v. WISCONSIN

opinion_summary: struck down a tennessee requirement that applicants for a license to operate a retail liquor store have resided in the state for the prior two years. held that the residency requirement violates the commerce clause because it blatantly favors the state's residents and has little relationship to public health and safety, and further held that the twenty-first amendment does not save the state law. justice alito delivered the opinion of the - court.
name: TENNESSEE WINE & SPIRITS RETAILERS ASSOCIATION v. THOMAS

opinion_summary: held that the government's decision to add a citizenship question to the  census questionnaire did not violate the enumeration clause or the census act. however, the sole stated reason for reinstating the question seems to have been contrived, and therefore it was appropriate to remand the case back to the agency on that ground. chief justice roberts delivered the court's opinion, some portions of which were unanimous while others received the support of only four justices in various groupings.
name: DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE v. NEW YORK

opinion_summary: holding that the united states may pursue claims interceding in an action relating to the rio grande compact establishing water supply agreements between colorado, new mexico, and texas because the court has authority to permit the federal government to participate in compact suits to defend the distinctively federal interests that a normal litigant might not be permitted to pursue in traditional litigation.
name: TEXAS v. NEW MEXICO AND COLORADO

opinion_summary: remanded to special master for further findings. florida sued georgia over equitably apportioning of water from an interstate river basin. the supreme court, exercising original jurisdiction, appointed a special master. the special master recommended dismissing the florida complaint. the court held that the special master applied too strict of a standard and stating that further findings are needed to determine as there has been no determination key remedy-related matters.
name: FLORIDA v. GEORGIA

opinion_summary: plaintiffs' claims that pedicle screw injuries would not have been caused but for the manufacturer's fraudulent misrepresentations to the food and drug administration are pre-empted by  usc .
name: BUCKMAN COMPANY v. Plaintiffs' LEGAL COMMITTEE

opinion_summary: indianapolis narcotics checkpoint program violates the fourth amendment because the primary purpose of the program is to uncover evidence of ordinary criminal wrongdoing rather than policing the border or ensuring roadway safety.
name: CITY OF INDIANAPOLIS, et al. v. JAMES EDMOND et al.

opinion_summary: public policy, as evidenced by department of transportation regulations, is to allow employers the freedom to rehabilitate truck drivers who test positive for drugs, so the arbitration award reinstating an employee who twice tested positive is not contrary to public policy.
name: EASTERN ASSOCIATED COAL CORPORATION v. UNITED MINE WORKERS OF AMERICA, DISTRICT 17, et al.

opinion_summary: police with probable cause to believe that petitioner had illegal drugs in his home acted reasonably in restraining him from entering his home unattended for the two hours it took to secure a search warrant, given the reasonable fear that petitioner would destroy evidence if not restrained.
name: ILLINOIS v. CHARLES MCARTHUR

opinion_summary: title  cfr .(a)() exceeds the authority of the clean water act at  usc (a) (regulating the discharge of dredged or fill material into navigable waters) when applied to an abandoned sand and gravel pit which provides habitat for migratory birds.
name: SOLID WASTE AGENCY OF NORTHERN COOK COUNTY v. UNITED STATES ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, et al.

opinion_summary: washington state's community protection act of  (act), which authorizes the civil commitment of sexually violent predators, cannot be deemed punitive as applied to a single individual in violation of the double jeopardy and ex post facto clauses.
name: MARK SELING, SUPERINTENDENT, SPECIAL COMMITMENT CENTER v. ANDRE BRIGHAM YOUNG

opinion_summary: an order compelling arbitration and dismissing a party's underlying claims is a final decision with respect to an arbitration within the meaning of the federal arbitration act,  usc , and thus is immediately appealable. arbitration agreements are enforceable even when they are silent as to arbitration costs and fees.
name: GREEN TREE FINANCIAL CORP.-ALABAMA AND GREEN TREE FINANCIAL CORPORATION v. LARKETTA RANDOLPH

opinion_summary: u. s. c. (d)(), the tolling provision of the antiterrorism and effective death penalty act of , applies to properly filed applications regardless of whether state law bars the claim on procedural grounds.
name: CHRISTOPHER ARTUZ, SUPERINTENDENT, GREEN HAVEN CORRECTIONAL FACILITY v. TONY BRUCE BENNETT

opinion_summary: state employees may not sue in federal court to recover money damages for the state's failure to comply with the ada because congress' abrogation of the eleventh amendment was not based upon an identified a pattern of irrational and unconstitutional state discrimination in employment against the disabled.
name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA, et al., v. PATRICIA GARRETT, et al.

opinion_summary: the clean air act, at  usc (b), does not permit the administrator to consider implementation costs in setting national ambient air quality standards, nor does it delegate legislative power to the epa.
name: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN, ADMINISTRATOR OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, et al. v. AMERICAN TRUCKING ASSOCIATIONS, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: usc (a) provides only that an insolvent s corporation's discharge of debt ceases to be included in gross income, but does not change the character of the discharge as an item of income, so taxpayers may thus increase their basis in the shares and deduct suspended losses.
name: DAVID A. GITLITZ, ET UX., et al. v. COMMISSIONER OF INTERNAL REVENUE

opinion_summary: state courts may adjudicate personal injury claims against vessel owners pursuant to the savings clause of  usc () so long as the vessel owner's right to seek limitation of liability is protected.
name: JAMES F. LEWIS v. LEWIS & CLARK MARINE, INC., ETC.

opinion_summary: the federal arbitration act, at  usc , does not exempt all employment contracts subject to congress' commerce power, but rather only the employment contracts of transportation workers.
name: CIRCUIT CITY STORES, INC. v. SAINT CLAIR ADAMS

opinion_summary: the fourth amendment does not forbid a warrantless arrest for a minor criminal offense, such as a misdemeanor seatbelt violation, punishable only by a fine.
name: GAIL ATWATER, et al. v. CITY OF LAGO VISTA et al.

opinion_summary: a tariff classification has no claim to judicial deference under chevron, there being no indication that congress intended such a ruling to carry the force of law, but the ruling is eligible to claim respect according to its persuasiveness.
name: UNITED STATES v. MEAD CORPORATION

opinion_summary: usc (a) preempts state statutes which directly conflict with erisa's requirements that plans be administered in accordance with plan documents, because such statutes have a connection with erisa plans.
name: DONNA RAE EGELHOFF v. SAMANTHA EGELHOFF, A MINOR, BY AND THROUGH HER NATURAL PARENT KATE BREINER, AND DAVID EGELHOFF

opinion_summary: because diversity jurisdiction incorporates state claim-preclusion law, federal law giving res judicata effect to judgments based on a state statute of limitations would violate the rules enabling act,  usc (b).
name: SEMTEK INTERNATIONAL INCORPORATED v. LOCKHEED MARTIN CORPORATION

opinion_summary: a mechanism for keeping portable signs erect in a high wind, which has not otherwise established secondary meaning in its trade dress, is a functional feature for which there is no trade dress protection, as shown by the fact that the expired patent was a utility patent.
name: TRAFFIX DEVICES, INC. v. MARKETING DISPLAYS, INC.

opinion_summary: inmates do not possess first amendment right to provide legal assistance to other prisoners.
name: ROBERT SHAW, et al.  v. KEVIN MURPHY

opinion_summary: where adult bookstore has ceased operations, controversy over whether a failure to relicense constitutes prior restraint of expression is moot.
name: CITY NEWS AND NOVELTY, INC. v. CITY OF WAUKESHA

opinion_summary: where journalists played no part in the unlawful interception of private communications and the substance of the communications regarded a matter of public interest, the first amendment protects the disclosure of the communications even where journalists knew that the communications were intercepted unlawfully.
name: BARTNICKI et al. v. VOPPER, AKA WILLIAMS, et al.

opinion_summary: the sixth amendment right to counsel does not extend from one custodial interrogation to a separate custodial interrogation even if the second interrogation is about a factually related charge.
name: TEXAS v. RAYMOND LEVI COBB

opinion_summary: section (a)() of erisa does not allow an employee health plan to seek to impose personal contractual liability on a plan beneficiary under the plan's reimbursement provision, because such relief is legal rather than equitable.
name: GREAT-WEST LIFE & ANNUITY INSURANCE COMPANY, et al. v. JANETTE KNUDSON AND ERIC KNUDSON

opinion_summary: while  usc  does not contain an express statements that banks for cooperatives are subject to state taxation, nothing in the statute indicates a repeal of the previous express approval of state taxation, and the structure of the farm credit act indicates by negative implication that banks for cooperatives are not entitled to immunity.
name: DIRECTOR OF REVENUE OF MISSOURI v. COBANK ACB, AS SUCCESSOR TO THE NATIONAL BANK OF COOPERATIVES

opinion_summary: in an unfair labor practice proceeding, the burden remains on the employer to establish the employee's supervisory status, and congress did not incorporate the board's categorical restrictions on independent judgment when it first added supervisor to  usc (a).
name: NATIONAL LABOR RELATIONS BOARD v. KENTUCKY RIVER COMMUNITY CARE, INC., et al.

opinion_summary: arbitration agreement between employer and employee for employment related disputes does not preclude the eeoc from seeking judicial relief on the employee's behalf.
name: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION v. WAFFLE HOUSE, INC.

opinion_summary: the term prevailing party for purposes of attorneys' fee awards does not include a party where litigation brought about a voluntary change in the defendant-s conduct, but neverthelss failed to secure a judgment on the merits or a court-ordered consent decree.
name: BUCKHANNON BOARD AND CARE HOME, INC., et al. v. WEST VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN RESOURCES, et al.

opinion_summary: a party alleging that a district was improperly drawn in favor of minority group must at least show that the legislature could have achieved non-discrimminatory objectives by other means, where racial identification has a high correlation with party affiliation.
name: MICHAEL F. EASLEY, * GOVERNOR OF NORTH CAROLINA, et al. v. MARTIN CROMARTIE, et al.

opinion_summary: communications between indian tribes and the department of the interior are not exempt under  usc (b)() from foia's disclosure requirements as inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters because the tribes are not like paid consultants.
name: DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR AND BUREAU OF INDIAN AFFAIRS v. KLAMATH WATER USERS PROTECTIVE ASSOCIATION

opinion_summary: federal postconviction relief is not available when a prisoner challenges a current sentence on the ground that it was enhanced based on an allegedly unconstitutional prior conviction for which the petitioner is no longer in custody.
name: LACKAWANNA COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY, et al. v. EDWARD R. COSS, JR.

opinion_summary: private individuals may not sue to enforce disparate-impact regulations promulgated under title vi of the civil rights act of ,  usc d et seq.
name: JAMES ALEXANDER, DIRECTOR, ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY, et al. v. MARTHA SANDOVAL, INDIVIDUALLY AND ON BEHALF OF ALL OTHERS SIMILARLY SITUATED

opinion_summary: before filing suit in court, an inmate seeking only money damages must complete a prison administrative process that could provide some sort of relief on the complaint stated, even if the administrative process can result in no award of money.
name: TIMOTHY BOOTH v. C. O. CHURNER, et al.

opinion_summary: in determining whether qualified immunity applies in civil rights cases, courts must determine whether a right was clearly established in light of the cases' specific contexts, not as a broad general proposition.
name: DONALD SAUCIER v. ELLIOT M. KATZ AND IN DEFENSE OF ANIMALS

opinion_summary: a tribal court may not assert jurisdiction over civil claims against state officials who enter tribal land to execute a search warrant against a tribe member suspected of having violated state law outside the reservation.
name: NEVADA, et al. v. FLOYD HICKS, et al.

opinion_summary: newly developed plant breeds are subject to  usc  of the patent act and neither the plant patent act of  or plant variety protection act preclude coverage under section .
name: J. E. M. AG SUPPLY, INC., DBA FARM ADVANTAGE, INC., et al. v. PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL, INC.

opinion_summary: the constitution requires that appellate courts review punitive damages awards using a de novo standard rather than a deferential standard.
name: COOPER INDUSTRIES, INC. v. LEATHERMAN TOOL GROUP, INC.

opinion_summary: government actors may not exclude speech from a limited public forum on the basis of the religious nature of the speech, because the exclusion constitutes unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination without justification by the establishment clause.
name: GOOD NEWS CLUB, et al. v. MILFORD CENTRAL SCHOOL

opinion_summary: a landowner may challenge state rules or regulations under the takings clause even if the enactment took place prior to transfer of title.
name: ANTHONY PALAZZOLO v. RHODE ISLAND, et al.

opinion_summary: usc (a), setting forth citizenship requirements for one born out of wedlock and abroad to a citizen father and a noncitizen mother, does not violate equal protection simply by use of gender specific terms because of the biological difference between the parents.
name: TUAN ANH NGUYEN AND JOSEPH BOULAIS v. IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE

opinion_summary: section (a)() of the omnibus consolidated rescissions and appropriations act of , which excludes lsc representation in cases which involve an effort to amend or otherwise challenge existing law, violates the first amendment and distorts the legal system by altering the traditional role of the attorneys.
name: LEGAL SERVICES CORPORATION v. CARMEN VELAZQUEZ, et al.

opinion_summary: retroactive abolishment of a common law rule does not violate the due process clause of the th amendment, unless the judicial action is unexpected and indefensible by reference to the law which had been expressed prior to the conduct in issue.
name: WILBERT K. ROGERS v. TENNESSEE

opinion_summary: the federal bureau of prisons has the discretion to consider preconviction conduct when implementing congress' goal of rewarding nonviolent offenders who complete a substance abuse program.
name: CHRISTOPHER A. LOPEZ v. RANDY J. DAVIS, WARDEN, et al.

opinion_summary: under  usc (a)(), the government may detain aliens admitted to the united states but subsequently ordered removed beyond the normal  day period, but only for a period reasonably necessary to secure the aliens removal.
name: KESTUTIS ZADVYDAS v. CHRISTINE G. DAVIS AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE

opinion_summary: the federal mail fraud statute,  u. s. c. , does not cover false statements made in an application for a state license because permits and licenses are not property for purposes of the fraud statute.
name: CARL W. CLEVELAND v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: the government's use of a device that is not in general public use, to explore details of a private home that would previously have been unknowable without physical intrusion, is a fourth amendment search and presumptively unreasonable without a warrant.
name: DANNY LEE KYLLO v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: even minimal jail time can qualify as prejudice for strickland purposes. an incorrect sentencing calculation can be corrected on appeal, but not if courts set up arbitrary guidelines about whether an increased sentence is significant.
name: PAUL L. GLOVER v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: in determining the scope of the immunity granted by the flood control act of ,  usc c, courts should consider the character of the waters that cause the relevant damage and the purposes behind their release rather than the relation between that damage and a flood control project.
name: CENTRAL GREEN CO. v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: an organization overwhelmingly composed of public school officials who act in their official capacity, whose members give up revenue in exchange for membership in the organization providing an integral element of secondary public schooling, is a state actor.
name: BRENTWOOD ACADEMY v. TENNESSEE SECONDARY SCHOOL ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION, et al.

opinion_summary: usc (e) requires appellat courts to give due deference to a district court's application of a sentencing guideline term to undisputed facts, such as whether an offender-s prior convictions were consolidated, and thus related, for purposes of sentencing.
name: PAULA L. BUFORD v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: after the sentencing proceeding has concluded, the defendant may not challenge his federal sentence through a motion under  usc  on the ground that his prior convictions were unconstitutionally obtained.
name: EARTHY D. DANIELS, JR. v. UNITED STATES

opinion_summary: states may not use ballots for congressional elections as a means of indirectly imposing restrictions on candidates for federal office because the constitution does not delegate such power under the elections clause.
name: REBECCA MCDOWELL COOK v. DONALD J. GRALIKE AND MIKE HARMAN

opinion_summary: the use of law enforcement to coerce pregnant women into substance abuse treatment does not justify a hospital conducting drug tests and turning the results over to law enforcement agents without the knowledge or consent of the patients.
name: CRYSTAL M. FERGUSON, et al. v. CITY OF CHARLESTON et al.

opinion_summary: awarding judgment against the state of wyoming and in favor of the state of montana on a bill of complaint relating to violations of the yellowstone river compact resulting in the reduction of the volume of water available to the state from the tongue river and awarding damages.
name: STATE OF MONTANA v. STATE OF WYOMING AND STATE OF NORTH DAKOTA
